office:text.text:p: The objective of this report is to describe requirements and technical specifications for the Open Accessibility Framework (OAF). It contains preparatory work for deliverable D1.2.1: “ÆGIS OAF and high-level architecture”. The bulk of the report covers the current state of play in accessibility on various platforms and thereby creates a “superset” of accessibility requirements.

text:p.text:span: briefly describes the problems with current and older access techniques and introduces the concept of “third-generation accessibility”, an engineered approach to accessibility that is intended to solve the issues with older bolted-on approaches to accessibility.

briefly describes a number of accessibility APIs and provides a concordance for the roles, states and properties for the main desktop accessibility APIs (on GNOME, Java, MS Windows, and Mac OS), with a mapping to WAI-ARIA.

discusses a range of accessibility features that are not covered by accessibility APIs: keyboard operation, theming support (including zooming and magnification), alternative input mechanisms and synthetic speech.

office:text.text:p: Chapter 4 briefly discusses requirements for user interface components, and chapter 5 briefly discusses requirements for developer tools.
Chapter 6 discusses a few relevant standards.

text:p.text:span: One of the main goals of the ÆGIS project is to demonstrate that third-generation access techniques provide a more accessible, more exploitable and more deeply embeddable approach in mainstream ICT than previous approaches. The project uses the Open Accessibility Framework (OAF) to reach this goal. The OAF addresses aspects of design, development and deployment that help making accessibility “business as usual”

text:note-body.text:p: The phrase “making accessibility business as usual” is borrowed from Graeme Whippy (Lloyds TSB and Employers’ Forum on Disability (EFD)).

text:h.text:span: Problems with Current and Older Ac

office:text.text:p: One of the technical aspects that complicate the development of assistive technologies (AT) is the fact that AT developers sometimes need to use several retrieval techniques to find the information that the user needs – including among them application-specific techniques and unsupported/reverse-engineering techniques, e.g. on Windows the MSAA accessibility API which is insufficient and so supplemented by several application-specific APIs (e.g. one for MS Word, another for MS Excel, another for Internet Explorer), and sometimes even video driver patching techniques. Some of these techniques may break when a new version of the platform or the application is released. This hybrid approach that is a blend of “second-generation accessibility” and some “third generation” (via the platform accessibility API) makes accessibility hard work, costly and insufficiently reliable. The second-generation approach to accessibility also saw the development of standards such as the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines 1.0 and legislation such as Section 508 in the USA and BITV in Germany.

The inconsistencies between applications and versions with regard to accessibility call for a single programming interface (on any given platform) that explicitly exposes every user interface component to assistive technologies and that defines a detailed set of information that each interface component must provide. This set of information and requirements is the “accessibility API”, which is one of the basic building blocks of “third-generation accessibility”. The Java Accessibility API and the GNOME accessibility API are examples of this. GNOME is the first desktop environment that has embraced third-generation access techniques.

The key feature of the third-generation approach to accessibility is “access by contract” or “programmatic accessibility”: each user interface component is a programmatic object with specific methods that assistive technologies can call to find out if the object is accessible, what it's name is etcetera. All applications on a specific platform or desktop (GNOME, Microsoft Windows, Java, etcetera) should conform to the same contract or API instead of having application-specific accessibility APIs. In the worst case, there may perhaps be two or three common/standard accessibility APIs on a given platform (e.g. MSAA and UI Automation and IAccessible2 on Windows). Using standard user interface components (which already support one of these accessibility APIs) in order to make an accessible application should require little work, but ideally making custom components accessible should not be too hard either. This means that developer tools need to provide easy access to accessibility APIs and their documentation. The chain from developer tools and accessibility APIs through content and user interface components to assistive technologies must not be broken. This chain constitutes the core of the Open Accessibility Framework.
The goal of the present deliverable is to define generic accessibility framework requirements and technical specifications. These requirements take existing examples as a starting point, namely:

text:list-item.text:p: the GNOME Accessibility Framework (and tools),
the Java Accessibility API (and tools, especially NetBeans),
IAccessible2,
W3C's WAI-ARIA,
Microsoft's UIAutomation,
the Macintosh Accessibility Framework.

office:text.text:p: The goal is to understand current accessibility practices and to answer questions such as:

text:list-item.text:p: What is successful and what isn't?
How well are these solutions integrated in the “accessibility value delivery chain”? What can we learn from this?
How well do these solutions layer on each other or communicate with each other? For example, how does Java accessibility interact with Windows accessibility?

office:text.text:p: The purpose of this chapter is to provide a mapping between existing accessibility APIs.
The “concordance table” in this section maps properties of major accessibility APIs and frameworks:

text:list-item.text:p: the GNOME Accessibility Framework:ATK Accessibility Toolkit: http://library.gnome.org/devel/atk/stable/,
the Java Accessibility API:Package javax.accessibility: http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/javax/accessibility/package-summary.html,
IAccessible2:IAccessible2 API Documentation version 1.0.2: http://a11y.org/a11yspecs/ia2/docs/html/,
Accesible Rich Internet Applications (WAI-ARIA) 1.0:Last Call Working Draft 24 February 2009: http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-wai-aria-20090224/,
UI Automation,
the Macintosh Accessibility framework.

text:p.text:span: GNOME is a desktop environment that is part of the GNU Project and that can be used with various Unix-like operating systems. GNOME’s accessibility project started in 2000

text:note-body.text:p: The GNOME Project: “The GNOME Community and Industry Leaders Join Forces to Deliver Enhanced User Environment for PCs, Workstations and New Internet Access Devices”, press release, 15 August 2000: http://www.gnome.org/press/releases/newcommitments.html.

text:p.text:span: . In 2001, the GNOME Foundation released the first version (“early access release”) of the GNOME 2.0 Accessibility Framework

text:note-body.text:p: The GNOME Project: “Making GNOME Accessible — Opening New Doors At the Workplace for Users with Disabilities”, press release, 28 August 2001: http://www.gnome.org/press/releases/accessible.html.

text:p.text:span: . This framework included a toolkit and APIs comprised of the following two key

text:list-item.text:p: “An Accessibility Toolkit (ATK API) and associated implementation library integrated with the GTK+ 2.0 user interface toolkit that provides built-in accessibility support - enabling developers using GTK+ widgets to automatically build accessible applications”

“An agnostic Assistive Technologies Service Provider Interface (AT SPI) toolkit for developers to interface technologies such as voice command, text-to-speech, screen readers, and screen magnifiers with GNOME accessible applications on any UNIX platform.”

text:p.text:span: GNOME Desktop version 2.0, in which these new features were integrated, was

text:note-body.text:p: The GNOME Project: “GNOME 2.0 Desktop and Developer Platform Released”, press release, 26 June 2002: http://www.gnome.org/press/releases/gnome20.html.

text:p.text:span: The GNOME Accessibility documentation is available at
the GNOME Desktop Accessibility Guide, which explains accessibility features available to users, including Orca and the GNOME On-Screen Keyboard (GOK):
; GAIL—GNOME Accessibility Implementation Library—is an implementation of the accessibility interfaces defined by ATK for GTK+ and GNOME libaries,
Catherine Laws (editor): Guidelines for Writing Accessible GNOME Applications Using GTK+ and the Accessibility Toolkit (ATK) (August 2006):
. This guide also contains a section called “Mapping MSAA and IAccessible2 to ATK”:

office:text.text:p: The Accessibility Toolkit (ATK) API is the interface through which assistive technologies receive information from applications. The API can be found in the atk module in the GNOME repositories.
A number of accessibility testing and evaluation tools for GNOME are also available:

text:list-item.text:p: Accerciser is an interactive Python accessibility explorer that uses AT-SPI to inspect and control widgets. It allows developers and testers “to check if an application is providing correct information to assistive technologies and automated test frameworks”.http://live.gnome.org/Accerciser.

dogtail is a GUI test tool and automation framework in Python. It enables GUI testers without expert programming skills to write (or record) and execute scripts. It also makes it easier to browse through the AT-SPI object hierarchy.https://fedorahosted.org/dogtail/.

The GNU/Linux Desktop Testing Project (GNU LDTP) aims to produce a test automation framework for graphical user interfaces. It can currently test GUIs in GNOME, OpenOffice.org, Java Swing, and KDE 4.0 applications based on QT 4.0.http://ldtp.freedesktop.org/wiki/.

pyatspi is a Python wrapper for AT-SPI and is used by Accerciser, dogtail, LDTP, the screen readers Orca and LSR, and the GUI test automation framework Strongwind5
http://medsphere.org/community/project/strongwind. .http://live.gnome.org/GAP/PythonATSPI.

office:text.text:p: The Linux Foundation has an ATK/AT-SPI Special Interest Group. Its project resources include an ATK/AT-SPI overview, ATK/AT-SPI references, best practices, tests and e-mail archives: http://www.linuxfoundation.org/en/Accessibility/ATK/AT-SPI.

GNOME’s user documentation contains a section on keyboard skills6
GNOME Documentation Library: Desktop User Guide: Keyboard Skills: http://library.gnome.org/users/user-guide/nightly/keyboard-skills.html. ; this section also points to guidance on keyboard accessibility preferences7
GNOME Documentation Library: Desktop User Guide: Keyboard Preferences: http://library.gnome.org/users/user-guide/nightly/prefs-keyboard.html.en#prefs-keyboard-a11y. .

The GNOME Outreach Program also has an accessibility section. This program aims to increase awareness of accessibility-related issues and help the free software community t improve its accessibility support: http://projects.gnome.org/outreach/a11y/. One of its tasks is to develop an accessibility testing strategy/framework: http://projects.gnome.org/outreach/a11y/tasks/testing/.
The GNOME Human Interface Guidelines (http://library.gnome.org/devel/hig-book/stable/), developed by the GNOME Usability Project, also mention the importance of accessibility.

There is also an open-source library that represents GNOME libraries—especially GTK—in Java: the java-gnome User Interface Library: http://java-gnome.sourceforge.net/. The package org.gnome.atk is the Java representation of GNOME’s ATK library: http://java-gnome.sourceforge.net/4.0/doc/api/org/gnome/atk/package-summary.html. However, the API documentation states that ATK is not yet implemented in java-gnome.

On the Java platform, user interface components need to implement the accessibility API, defined in the package javax.accessibility8
Package javax.accessibility: http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/javax/accessibility/package-summary.html , to enable access by assistive technologies. The accessibility API was first implemented in the Java Foundation Classes (JFC) and then released with JDK 1.2 in 1998 (Schwerdtfeger & Jenkins, 1998).

On the Microsoft Windows operating system, users also need the Java Access Bridge (JAB)9
Java SE Desktop Accessibility: Java Access Bridge for Windows OS: http://java.sun.com/javase/technologies/accessibility/accessbridge/index.jsp to allow their assistive technology to interact with the accessibility API. Sun also provides a set of Java accessibility utilities10
Java Accessibility Utilities Version 1.3: http://java.sun.com/javase/technologies/accessibility/docs/jaccess-1.3/doc/ .

On the GNOME desktop, users need the Java Access Bridge for GNOME, which connects the accessibility support in Java Swing applications to the Assistive Technology Service Provider Interface (AT-SPI).11
The GNOME Project: Java Access Bridge: http://live.gnome.org/Java Access Bridge The Java ATK Wrapper is meant to replace the Java Access Bridge. It is an implementation of ATK using Java Native Interface (JNI); it converts Java Swing events into ATK events and sends these events to the ATK-Bridge. This new wrapper is part of the Bonobo depreciation project.12
The GNOME Project: Java ATK Wrapper: http://live.gnome.org/Accessibility/JavaATKWrapper

When mapping roles and properties from other accessibility APIs to Java, one does not always find a counterpart in the package javax.accessibility. For example, support for accessibility in the abstract class javax.swing.JComponent is not achieved by implementing the interface javax.accessibility.Accessible; instead, JComponent contains all of the methods in that interface and defers the responsibility for implementing the Accessible interface to the individual classes that extend JComponent.13
JComponent (Java 2 Platform SE 5.0): http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/javax/swing/JComponent.html
Documentation on Java accessibility is very extensive and includes:

text:list-item.text:p: Sun’s documentation on Java SE Desktop Accessibility: http://java.sun.com/javase/technologies/accessibility/index.jsp,
API documentation for Package javax.accessibility (Java Platform SE 6): http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/javax/accessibility/package-summary.html,
the list of roles defined in the class javax.accessibility.AccessibleRole: http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/javax/accessibility/AccessibleRole.html,
the list of states defined in the class javax.accessibility.AccessibleState:http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/javax/accessibility/AccessibleState.html,
the list of relations in the class javax.accessibility.AccessibleRelations:http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/javax/accessibility/AccessibleRelation.html,

Java Accessibility Utilities: http://java.sun.com/javase/technologies/accessibility/downloads.jsp#download-access-1.3 (older documentation is still available at http://java.sun.com/javase/technologies/accessibility/docs/jaccess-1.3/doc/), ,

IBM Guidelines for Writing Accessible Applications Using 100% Pure Java: http://www-03.ibm.com/able/guidelines/java/snsjavag.html,14
IBM’s developer guidelines on Java accessibility (formerly at http://www-03.ibm.com/able/guidelines/java/accessjava.html) have been merged with the IBM Software accessibility checklist.
Jeff Dunn (Sun): “Developing Accessible JFC Applications” (June 2000): http://www.sun.com/accessibility/docs/dev_access_apps.jsp,
Dusan Pavlica and Chris LeDantec: “NetBeans Accessibility Guideline” (April 2002): http://a11y.netbeans.org/a11yDevGuide.html,
Dusan Pavlica and Chris LeDantec: “NetBeans Accessibility FAQ” (August 2002):http://a11y.netbeans.org/a11yFAQ.html,

Sun’s Java Accessibility Helper:Early Acces v0.8: http://java.sun.com/developer/earlyAccess/jaccesshelper/, http://java.sun.com/developer/earlyAccess/jaccesshelper/docs/index.html, http://www.j2ee.me/developer/earlyAccess/jaccesshelper/docs/start.html.
NetBeans Accessibility Testing Utilities (download page): http://www.sun.com/accessibility/downloads.jsp,

IBM Rule-based Accessibility Validation Environment (IBM alphaWorks, February 2006): a “suite of Eclipse plug-ins used to inspect and validate the accessibility of Java-based, rich-client GUIs (Swing or SWT) and Eclipse plug-ins”:http://www.alphaworks.ibm.com/tech/raven,
Sun’s Java Look and Feel Design Guidelines, 2nd edition (2001):http://java.sun.com/products/jlf/ed2/book/index.html (containing a chapter on “Designing for Accessibility”),
Mark Andrews’ article “Accessibility and the Swing Set” (April 2003): http://java.sun.com/products/jfc/tsc/articles/accessibility/,
Mark Pilgrim et at: “Creating accessible applications with Eclipse: An introduction” (December 2005): http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/rational/library/dec05/pilgrim/,
Sun’s forum for “Core GUI API’s – Accessibility”: http://forums.sun.com/forum.jspa?forumID=3.

office:text.text:p:
Microsoft Visual Studio versions 2003 and 2005 contained a Java Language Conversion Assistant that allowed developers to convert Visual J++ projects and Java-language files to Visual C#: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/1kwtxa08(VS.80).aspx. This conversion tool also converted a number of features of Java Accessibility: accessible classes, accessible contexts (partially) and accessible components15
Gaurav Seth’s Weblog: “JLCA 3.0 – Java Accessibility (JAAPI)”, 15 June 2006: http://blogs.msdn.com/gauravseth/archive/2006/06/15/632023.aspx. . Gaurav Seth, former Java Migration team member at Microsoft, has created a “cheat sheet” for users of the conversion tool “JLCA 3.0 – A Perspective: Cheat Sheet unleashed” (19 June 2006): http://blogs.msdn.com/gauravseth/archive/2006/06/19/636557.aspx.

IAccessible2 is an accessibility API that complements Microsoft Active Accessibility (MSAA; see below). IAccessible2 was originally developed by IBM in order to produce an accessible OpenDocument Format (ODF) based office suite for the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. IBM donated it to the Free Standards Group in December 2006.16
IBM Press Release, 14 December 2006: “IBM Helps Disabled Users Get More From Assistive Technology, on More Computer Platforms”: http://www-03.ibm.com/press/us/en/pressrelease/20773.wss

Even though it complements MSAA, IAccessible2 has been harmonised with the UNIX accessibility APIs in order to allow cross-platform development. It was also developed in close collaboration with leading AT vendors. The current version of the API is 1.2, released on 21 June 201017
Open A11y Workgroup: “IAccessible2 1.2 Released!” http://www.linuxfoundation.org/en/Accessibility/News/2010/06/21/IA2_1.2 .
Documentation and tools for IAccessible2 include:

text:list-item.text:p: “Accessibility/IAccessible2”, maintained by the Open Accessibility (A11y) Working Group of the Linux Foundation: http://www.linuxfoundation.org/en/Accessibility/IAccessible2.
An overview of IAccessible2: http://www.linuxfoundation.org/en/Accessibility/IAccessible2/Overview.
IAccessible2 API Documentation (version 1.0.2): http://accessibility.freestandards.org/a11yspecs/ia2/docs/html/,
AccessibleRole.idl File Reference (in the IAccessible2 API Documentation): http://a11y.org/a11yspecs/ia2/docs/html/_accessible_role_8idl.html.
A software directory that lists applications and assistive technologies that are known to implement IAccessible2: http://www.linuxfoundation.org/en/Accessibility/IAccessible2/SoftwareDirectory.

ACTF Accessibility Probe (AccProbe), an applications that provides a view of the MSAA or IAccessible2 hierarchy of a running application or a rendered document and of the properties of the accessible objects or the application or document being examined. It is meant to combine with tools like Microsoft’s Inspect32, AccExplore and AccEvent. http://www.eclipse.org/actf/downloads/tools/accprobe/index.php.
IBM: Open Source Accessibility for Windows: http://www-03.ibm.com/able/open_computing/open_source_windows.html.

office:text.text:p: Accessible Rich Internet Applications (WAI-ARIA) is a set of specifications being developed by the World Wide Web Consortium’s Web Accessibility Initiative (WAI). The goal of WAI-ARIA is to address the accessibility issues in rich internet applications (RIAs), which use non-standard ways to create user interface controls that are not defined in HTML or XHTML (for example, slides, collapsible menus, drag-and-drop functionality). These non-standard user interface controls make sense visually but are not identifiable by assistive technologies. WAI-ARIA provides Web authors or developers with the following:

text:list-item.text:p: Roles to describe the type of widget presented, such as "menu," "treeitem," "slider," and "progressmeter"
Roles to describe the structure of the Web page, such as headings, regions, and tables (grids)
Properties to describe the state widgets are in, such as "checked" for a check box, or "haspopup" for a menu.

Properties to define live regions of a page that are likely to get updates (such as stock quotes), as well as an interruption policy for those updates—for example, critical updates may be presented in an alert dialogue box, and incidental updates occur within the page
Properties for drag-and-drop that describe drag sources and drop targets
A way to provide keyboard navigation for the Web objects and events, such as those mentioned above (Quoted from: WAI: WAI-ARIA Overview).

office:text.text:p: The WAI-ARIA suite of documents consists of:

text:list-item.text:p: “Accessible Rich Internet Applications (WAI-ARIA) 1.0”, a planned W3C Recommendation. It replaces two previous drafts: “Roles for Accessible Rich Internet Applications” and “States and Properties Module for Accessible Rich Internet Application”. http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/.
“WAI-ARIA Primer”, a planned Working Group Note, first published in February 2008.http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-primer/.
“WAI-ARIA Best Practices”, a planned Working Group Note, first published in February 2008.http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-practices/.

“WAI-ARIA 1.0 User Agent Implementation Guide”, a planned Working Group Note, first published in February 2009.http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-implementation/.This document contains the most up-to-date mapping between WAI-ARIA roles and accessibility APIs. It maps WAI-ARIA roles to ATK/AT-SPI on UNIX, to MSAA/IAccessible 2 on Microsoft Windows and NSAccessibility on Mac OS; UIAutomation and the Java Accessibility API are not taken into account.
“Roadmap for Accessible Rich Internet Applications (WAI-ARIA Roadmap)”, a planned Working Group Note . http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-roadmap/.

office:text.text:p: The Protocols and Formats Working Group (PF WG), which develops the WAI-ARIA documents, also has drafts of documents outside the regular publishing space for W3C Recommendations and Working Group Notes:

text:list-item.text:p: “States and Adaptable Properties Module: A Syntax for adding accessible state information and author settable properties for XML”. This document has not been updated since November 2005. Appendix C contains a mapping between the proposed states and properties and accessibility APIs.http://www.w3.org/WAI/PF/adaptable/StatesAndProperties-20051106.html.
“Dynamic Accessible Web Content Roadmap”, last updated in April 2006, and superseded by the WAI-ARIA Roadmap listed above.http://www.w3.org/WAI/PF/roadmap/DHTMLRoadmap040506.html.

“Role Taxonomy for Accessible Adaptable Applications Working Draft: An RDF Role Taxonomy with Qname Support for Accessible Adaptable XML Applications”, last updated in May 2006. The role taxonomy has been integrated into the WAI-ARIA specification listed above. The WAI-ARIA specification contains a formal representation of the role taxonomy in Web Ontology Language (OWL), an implementation of Resource Description Framework (RDF).http://www.w3.org/WAI/PF/GUI/roleTaxonomy-20060508.html.

The User Agent Implementation Task Force also collects information on implementations in a wiki:http://www.w3.org/WAI/PF/wiki/User_Agent_Implementation_Task_Force. This contains among other documents:
HTML 4.x as-built browser comparison: http://www.w3.org/WAI/PF/wiki/HTML_4.x_as-built_browser_comparison.
ARIA as-built browser comparison:http://www.w3.org/WAI/PF/wiki/ARIA_as-built_browser_comparison (based on test by Steve Faulkner, see below).

office:text.text:p: Support for WAI-ARIA in browsers, assistive technologies and other software is evolving quickly. Both browser developers/vendors and third parties (accessibility experts, researchers, etcetera) have been publishing information on WAI-ARIA implementations.

text:list-item.text:p:
In March 2009, Steve Faulkner compared support for WAI-ARIA roles in Windows browsers: “WAI-ARIA role support - How the browsers stack up”: http://www.paciellogroup.com/blog/?p=114. This compared Safari 4 beta, Opera 10 Alpha, Internet Explorer 8 release candidate 1, Firefox 3.2a1 (Minefield) and Chrome 1.0.154.4818
The results table is available at http://www.paciellogroup.com/blog/aria-tests/ARIA-SafariaOperaIEFF.html. , all on Windows Vista. The results table show that some WAI-ARIA roles have no mapping in MSAA (the roles article, banner, complementary, contentinfo, definition, main, navigation, note and search) but the author states that the role information may be exposed to assistive technology through another API (IAccessible2 or UIAutomation).

In March 2009, Steve Faulkner also compared support for WAI-ARIA roles in Mac browsers: “WAI-ARIA role support – How the MAC browsers stack up”: http://www.paciellogroup.com/blog/?p=123. This compared Safari 4 beta, Firefox 3.2a1 (Minefield) and Opera 10 Alpha19
The results table is available at http://www.paciellogroup.com/blog/aria-tests/ARIA-MACRoleTests.html. .

Internet Explorer 8 is the first version of Microsoft's browser with support for WAI-ARIA. See “Mapping ARIA Roles, States, and Properties to UI Automation”: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc891505(VS.85).aspx.

WebKit, the open-source web browser layout engine used in Apple Safari, has some support for WAI-ARIA. A list of supported accessibility roles is available at http://developer.apple.com/safari/library/documentation/AppleApplications/Reference/SafariHTMLRef/Articles/AccessibilityRoles.html.

“Contributing WAI-ARIA landmark roles to open source CMS themes” (28 March 2009) is call by Peter Krantz to implement WAI-ARIA landmarks in open-source content management systems (CMS).http://www.standards-schmandards.com/2009/wai-aria-landmark-roles-in-cms-themes/.

office:text.text:h: Microsoft Active Accessibility and UI Automation
office:text.text:p:
Microsoft Active Accessibility (MSAA) was first released in 1997 as an add-on for the English version of Windows 95. Microsoft Active Accessibility was released in 1999 and supported all 27 Microsoft Windows languages. MSAA 3.0 was integrated into the Windows Automation API, which also includes User Interface Automation (UI Automation).20
Microsoft: “History of Microsoft's Commitment to Accessibility”: http://www.microsoft.com/enable/microsoft/history.aspx.

Microsoft User Interface Automation (UIA) is an accessibility API that provides a richer object model than the older Microsoft Active Accessibility API (MSAA). It is compatible with both the Windows API (also known as Win32 API) and the .NET Framework. UI Automation is an “open specification” covered by the UI Automation Community Promise21
Microsoft: UI Automation Community Promise: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/accessibility/bb892136.aspx .

UI Automation provides full functionality in Windows Vista, Microsoft Windows XP, and Windows Server 2003. UI Automation providers offer some support for Microsoft Active Accessibility client applications, through a built-in bridging service. It is expected to be included in the future release of Windows 7.

The Mono project develops an open source implementation of Microsoft’s .NET Framework based on the ECMA standards for C# (ECMA 334) and the Common Language Runtime (ECMA 335) so C# applications can also be developed for Linux. The Mono Accessibility project22
http://mono-project.com/Accessibility implemented a bridge between Mono’s UI Automation implementation and ATK23
Mono Project: Accessibility: UiaAtkBridge: http://www.mono-project.com/Accessibility:_UiaAtkBridge . Mono Accessibility 2.0 was released on February 2010.24
Mono Accessibility 2.0 Release Notes: http://mono-project.com/Accessibility:_Release_Notes_2.0
Microsoft provides both introductory articles and technical guidance (development guides, API references, etcetera) for developers, for example:

text:list-item.text:p: Microsoft Developer Network: Accessibility: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa163327.aspx: a general starting point with links to the relevant APIs.
Rob Sinclair: “Microsoft Active Accessibility: Architecture” (May 2000): http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms971310.aspx.
Rob Sinclair: “Microsoft Active Accessibility: Architecture” (July 2000):http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms971352.aspx.

Microsoft Active Accessibility, Version 2.0: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms697707(VS.85).aspx. (Developers can find a list of “roles” for this older MSAA version in the C/C++ Reference: Active Accessibility User Interface Services: Constants and Enumerated Types. See http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd373608(VS.85).aspx.A list of states can be found in “Object State Constants”:http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd373609(VS.85).aspx.)

Windows Automation API: Microsoft Active Accessibility: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd373592(VS.85).aspx: starting point with links to information to get started, a developer’s guide, a C/C++ reference and other information.

UI Automation and Microsoft Active Accessibility: describes the main features of UI Automation and contains a mapping between MSAA roles and UI Automation control types:http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms788733.aspx.
Magnification API SDK: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms692162(VS.85).aspx. This API enables the development of screen magnification applications for Windows Vista.
Windows Automation API: UI Automation: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms726294(VS.85).aspx.
.NET Framework 3.0: UI Automation Overview: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms747327(VS.85).aspx.
.NET Framework 3.5: UI Automation Overview:http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms747327.aspx.
.NET Framework 4 Beta 1: UI Automation Overview: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms747327(VS.100).aspx.
A list of object roles:http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd373608(VS.85).aspx.
UI Automation Community Promise Specification: http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyID=A1FE1066-BF4F-44FC-834B-676B311E83A2&displaylang=en (download page).

Inspect Objects, a Windows Automation-based tool for inspecting and testing IAccessible COM interfaces and user interfaces25
This tool and the Accessible Event Watcher (AccEvent.exe) used to ship with the Microsoft Accessibility Package (MSAA SDK) but are currently included in the Windows SDK. See “Where did the accessibility tools go?” MSDN Blog, 22 July 2010: http://blogs.msdn.com/b/seealso/archive/2010/07/22/where-did-the-accessibility-tools-go.aspx :http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd318521(VS.85).aspx.

Accessible Explorer, a tool that allows developers to examine the IAccessible properties of objects and how objects are related to each other: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd317980(VS.85).aspx.

Accessible Event Watcher (AccEvent), a tool that allows developers to check that user interface elements raise proper Active Accessibility events when the user interface changes:http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd317979(VS.85).aspx.

Microsoft Download Center: “Active Accessibility 2.0 SDK Tools”, a download page for the above tools: http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?familyid=3755582A-A707-460A-BF21-1373316E13F0&displaylang=en.

UI Accessibility Checker (AccChecker), an open-source tool that enables testers without prior experience to discover accessibility problems with MSAA and other user interfaces on Windows:http://www.codeplex.com/AccCheck.

UI Automation Verify (UIA Verify) Test Automation Framework, an open-source test automation framework for manual and automated testing of the Microsoft User Interface Automation Provider implementation of a control or application:http://www.codeplex.com/UIAutomationVerify.

WindowCatcher is an open-source “utility that searches any user interface in Windows XP or Vista for MSAA and UIAutomation information and makes this available to assistive technology interfaces”. It was developed by the ACE Centre (UK) requires the Microsoft .NET 3.0 framework.http://www.oatsoft.org/Software/windowcatcher (user view),http://www.oatsoft.org/Software/windowcatcher/forge_product_view (developer view).

office:text.text:p: In Mac OS X version 10.2 (August 2002), Apple introduced the accessibility framework, which includes:

text:list-item.text:p: The accessibility protocol that both the Carbon and Cocoa APIs implement to allow access by assistive technologies,
APIs that assisitive technologies use to drive the user interface of another application running under Mac OS X.

office:text.text:p:
Apple points out that if a Mac application uses only standard, non-custom Carbon or Cocoa objects, most of the application is already accessible, but a few things remain to be done. The accessibility documentation also points out that Java developers should implement the Java Accessibility API and that Swing and AWT interfaces are also accessible. Since Mac OS X Leopard, “Cocoa accessibility information is (...) correctly reported for Cocoa windows used in a Carbon application, as well as Cocoa views embedded into Carbon windows via the new Carbon HICocoaView.”26
Mac OS X Leopard Developer Release Notes – Cocoa Aplication Framework: http://developer.apple.com/releasenotes/Cocoa/AppKit.html#Accessibility.
The documentation and tools for Mac OS accessibility include:

text:list-item.text:p: “User Experience: Accessibility”, a general starting point in the “Apple Developer Connection”: http://developer.apple.com/ue/accessibility/index.html.
The Mac OS X Accessibility Protocol: http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Accessibility/Conceptual/AccessibilityMacOSX/OSXAXModel/OSXAXmodel.html,

Roles and Associated Attributes (in Appendix B of the Accessibility Overview): http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Accessibility/Conceptual/AccessibilityMacOSX/OSXAXRoleReference/OSXAXRoleReference.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40001078-CH211-CHDIGFBH. Developers can use this information when creating accessibility objects that represent custom user interface objects. The overview uses generic value types; developers must convert these value types to the ones that are specific to the application framework they are using: Carbon or Cocoa.

The “NSAccessibility Protocol Reference”, which defines methods that Cocoa classes (using the Objective-C language) must implement to interact with assistive technologies: http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Cocoa/Reference/ApplicationKit/Protocols/NSAccessibility_Protocol/Reference/Reference.html.

The “Carbon Accessibility Reference”, which describes the Carbon accessibility API (for applications in the C programming language): http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Accessibility/Reference/AccessibilityCarbonRef/Reference/reference.html.

The Accessibility Inspector and the Accessibility Verifier, which enable developers to test the accessibility for their applications:http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Accessibility/Conceptual/AccessibilityMacOSX/OSXAXTesting/OSXAXTestingApps.html.
UIElementInspector, a sample that demonstrates the use of the Accessibility API in a Cocoa application:http://developer.apple.com/samplecode/UIElementInspector/index.html.
Articles on Carbon assessibility, such as “Empowering Your Carbon Application with the VoiceOver Accessibility Reference”: http://devworld.apple.com/ue/accessibility/voiceoverincarbon.html.

Articles on Cocoa accessibility such as “Enabling Accessibility in Your Cocoa Application” and “Adding Accessibility Support in Custom Views in Your Cocoa Application” (two-part article), at (respectively)http://developer.apple.com/ue/accessibility/accessibilityincocoa.htmlandhttp://developer.apple.com/ue/accessibility/accessibilitycustomviews.html.
Accessibility-dev, a mailing list for wishing to use Apple's Accessibility APIs:http://www.lists.apple.com/mailman/listinfo/accessibility-dev.

office:text.text:p: The desktop APIs mentioned in the preceding subsections have been available for some time or replace older accessibility APIs. More recently, vendors have been introducing new APIs for the mobile platform.

RIM released an accessibility API for Blackberry. The documentation for “Package net.rim.device.api.ui.accessibility” is available athttp://docs.blackberry.com/en/developers/deliverables/6022/net/rim/device/api/ui/accessibility/package-summary.html.

The API is part of the BlackBerry Java Development Environment (JDE)27
BlackBerry Java Development Environment (JDE) 4.6.1: API Reference: http://docs.blackberry.com/en/developers/deliverables/6022/overview-summary.html. , a Mobile Information Device Profile (MIDP) and Connected Limited Device Configuration (CLDC) compliant J2ME environment. The accessibility API includes the interface AccessibleRole, which enumerates a number of common object roles:
http://docs.blackberry.com/en/developers/deliverables/6022/net/rim/device/api/ui/accessibility/AccessibleRole.html.

RIM also provides a development guide for accessible Java applications on BlackBerry smartphones28
Blackberry Java Application – Accessibility – Development Guide: http://docs.blackberry.com/en/developers/deliverables/9118/. . In addition, the website BlackBerry Accessibility29
BlackBerry Accessibility: http://na.blackberry.com/eng/support/devices/blackberry_accessibility/. provides information on features that facilitate smartphone use by persons with disabilities.

Humanware has released Oratio (orginally known as Orator30
HumanWare: “Introducing Orator for BlackBerry Smartphones”, October 27, 2009: http://www.humanware.ca/web/en/newsletter/71-t.htm ), a screenreader for BlackBerry smartphones (QUERTY models):
http://www.humanware.com/en-usa/products/blindness/orator_for_blackberry_smartphones/_details/id_131/orator_for_blackberry_smartphones.html.
Apple has released the iPhone Accessibility API:
http://developer.apple.com/iPhone/library/documentation/UserExperience/Conceptual/iPhoneAccessibility/Accessibility_on_iPhone/Accessibility_on_iPhone.html.

The documentation also describes how to turn on the Accessibility Inspector on the iPhone and how to test applications with VoiceOver, Apple’s screenreader. (VoiceOver is built into iPhone 3GS.31
Apple: Accessibility: iPhone: Vision: http://www.apple.com/accessibility/iphone/vision.html. )

Android is a mobile operating system initially developed by Google and later by the Open Handset Alliance (OHA)32
Open Handset Alliance: “Industry Leaders Announce Open Platform for Mobile Devices”, press release 12 November 2007, http://www.openhandsetalliance.com/press_110507.html. . It is built on the Linux 2.6 kernel. Android 1.6 was released in September 2009 and is available under an Apache License;33
Boulton, Clint (21 October 2008). "Google Open-Sources Android on Eve of G1 Launch". eWeek. http://www.eweek.com/c/a/Mobile-and-Wireless/Google-Open-Sources-Android-on-Eve-of-G1-Launch/. Android 2.0 is not available as open source software. Developers who want to build applications for Android need 34
Open Handset Alliance: “Open Handset Alliance Releases Android SDK”, press release 12 November 2007, http://www.openhandsetalliance.com/press_111207.html.

text:list-item.text:p: the Android SDK;
an x86-based computer running Windows XP or Vista, Mac OS X 10.4.8 or later; or Linux Ubuntu Dapper Drake or later;

Eclipse 3.2 or later35
Eclipse is the officially supported IDE; developers can also use any other editor to edit Java and XML files and use other tools to compile, build and debug applications., with Java Development Tools and the Android SDK's plugin, or Java and Javac 1.5 or 1.6;
Apache Ant;
Python 2.2 or later.

office:text.text:p: Developers can also use languages other than Java. Applications in C and other languages can be compiled to ARM native code. There are certain restrictions and issues for developers:

text:list-item.text:p:
The Linux kernel used by Android is not a conventional Linux distribution; it does not have a native X Window System and does not support the full set of GNU libraries.36
Paul, Ryan (23 February 2009). "Dream(sheep++): A developer's introduction to Google Android". Ars Technica. http://arstechnica.com/open-source/reviews/2009/02/an-introduction-to-google-android-for-developers.ars.

Android uses a non-standard C library known as Bionic.37
For the differences between Bionic and Standard C, see the text document attached to David Turner’s message at http://groups.google.com/group/android-platform/browse_thread/thread/bb85ef641ed093ea (7 February 2009).For another overview, see Denton Gentry; “The Six Million Dollar LibC” 28 November 2008: http://codingrelic.geekhold.com/2008/11/six-million-dollar-libc.html.

Android does not use established Java standards (Java SE, Java ME): it reuses the Java language syntax without providing the full-class libraries and APIs bundled with Java SE or ME.38
van Gurp, Jilles (13 November 2007). "Google Android: Initial Impressions and Criticism". Javalobby. http://www.javalobby.org/nl/archive/jlnews_20071113o.html.

office:text.text:p:
Android 1.6 was released in September 2009 and added a new accessibility framework39
Android Deelopers: “Android 1.6 Platform Highlights”: http://developer.android.com/sdk/android-1.6-highlights.html. . The SDK included for new packages, including “android.accessibilityservice”, “android.view.accessibility” and “android.speech.tts”40
“Android API Differences Report”: http://developer.android.com/sdk/api_diff/4/changes/changes-summary.html. . The class android.accessibilityservice.AccessibilityService is a service that runs in the background and receives callbacks by the system when AccessibilityEvents are fired. The accessibility framework generates android.view.accessibility.AccessibilityEvent in response to user interaction events. This object contains additional details about the event, for example, the user interface control that received focus. The SDK also contains a set of free voices for English (US and UK), French, Italian, German and Spanish41
Charles Chen, Svetoslav Ganov and T.V. Raman: “TalkBack: An Open Source Screenreader For Android”, 20 October 2009 (“Open Source at Google” blog): http://google-opensource.blogspot.com/2009/10/talkback-open-source-screenreader-for.html. .
Developers have started working on screen readers and other assistive technologies for Android:

text:list-item.text:p:
slimvoice is a set of Braille drivers and a screen reader: http://code.google.com/p/slimvoice/42
The slimvoice project initially struggled with the absence of an accessibility API: see “Android accessibility” discussion, 15 July 2009: http://groups.google.com/group/tts-for-android/browse_thread/thread/5c2100cc3f98c7be. .

Talkback is an open-source screen reader developed by Google: http://eyes-free.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/TalkBack/; http://google-opensource.blogspot.com/2009/10/talkback-open-source-screenreader-for.html.
Spiel is an open-source screen reader; the project was started by Nolan Darilek:http://spiel.thewordnerd.info/.
eyes-free is an open-source project by Google that develops a TTS library that can be used by Android applications: http://code.google.com/p/eyes-free/.

The IDEAL Android Accessibility Wizard enables “retail store personnel selling Android smartphones (and end-users) to activate, install and make use of screenreading and other advanced eyes-free applications”: http://accessibility-android.info/.

The vOICe for Android is an application that “ adds an auditory augmented reality overlay to the live camera view in real-time, thereby giving even totally blind people live and detailed information about their visual environment that they would otherwise not perceive”: http://www.seeingwithsound.com/android.htm.

office:text.text:p: OpenOffice.org is a cross-platform application with support for assistive technologies. It uses the UNO Accessibility API (UAA), which is modelled on the Java Accessibility API in Java 1.4 and the GNOME Accessibility API. The homepage of the UNO Accessibility API is at http://ui.openoffice.org/accessibility/unoapi.html. The homepage of the OpenOffice.org Accessibility project is at http://ui.openoffice.org/accessibility/.
OpenOffice.org exposes information to AT in different ways, depending on the platform:

text:list-item.text:p:
On Windows, OpenOffice.org exposes this information via the Java Accessibility API. Accessibility requires Java 1.5 or newer, and the Java Access Bridge43
See OpenOffice.org Wiki: Accessibility: http://wiki.services.openoffice.org/wiki/Accessibility. . Adding support for IAccessible2 is an ongoing effort44
See OpenOffice.org Wiki: Accessibility/IAccessible2 support: http://wiki.services.openoffice.org/wiki/Accessibility/IAccessible2_support. .

On Linux/Solaris with GNOME, it exposes accessibility information via the GNOME Accessibility API (ATK). To benefit from AT support, users need a current version of GNOME and activate AT support in GNOME’s preferences.45
See OpenOffice.org Wiki: Accessibility: http://wiki.services.openoffice.org/wiki/Accessibility.

On Mac OS, OpenOffice.org exposes accessibility information via the NSAccessibility protocol, so the office suite can be used with VoiceOver. 46
See OpenOffice.org Wiki: Accessibility/MacOSX: http://wiki.services.openoffice.org/wiki/Accessibility/MacOSX and Frank Neumann: Accessibility support on Mac OSX (Thursday, 24 July 2008, GullFOSS blog): http://blogs.sun.com/GullFOSS/entry/accessibility_support_on_mac_os.

office:text.text:p: The OpenOffice.org wiki states that AT support is better on GNOME than on Windows and provides a list of assistive technologies that are known to work with OpenOffice.org.

The Standard Widget Toolkit (SWT: http://www.eclipse.org/swt/) is an open source widget toolkit for Java. It was originally developed by IBM and is now maintained by the Eclipse Foundation. SWT is written in Java but the SWT implementation is unique for each platform. This allows the SWT implementation to access native GUI libraries – using Java Native Interface (JNI) – to display GUI elements.

Classes that support platform accessibility are available in the package org.eclipse.swt.accessibility: http://help.eclipse.org/stable/nftopic/org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/reference/api/org/eclipse/swt/accessibility/package-summary.html.
The class org.eclipse.swt.accessibility.Accessible provides a bridge between application code and assistive technologies.

The SWT Accessibility API was implemented for GTK (using GTK’s ATK) in Milestone 2 of Eclipse 3.047
“Eclipse 3.0 – New and Noteworthy in SWT”: http://www.eclipse.org/swt/R3_0/new_and_noteworthy.html. . On Windows, Eclipse uses Microsoft Active Accessibility (MSAA) to expose user interfaces elements to assistive technologies48
“Accessibility Features in Eclipse”: http://help.eclipse.org/stable/index.jsp?topic=/org.eclipse.platform.doc.user/concepts/accessibility/accessmain.htm. .

Tod Creasey wrote the article “Designing Accessible Plug-ins in Eclipse” (2006), which also contains an example of making an accessible view: http://www.eclipse.org/articles/article.php?file=Article-Accessibility/index.html.

WxWidgets (http://www.wxwidgets.org/49
Code repository at http://sourceforge.net/projects/wxwindows/. ; formerly known as wxWindows50
wxWidgets: Name Change: http://www.wxwidgets.org/about/name.htm. ) is an open-source GUI toolkit in C++ for cross-platform applications. It enables developers to create applications that run on 32-bit and 64-bit architectures, and that run on desktop environments such as Microsoft Windows, Mas OS X, Linux and Unix, and on mobile platforms such as Windows Mobile, the iPhone SDK and embedded GTK+. It has bindings for several programming languages, including Python (wxPython51
http://sourceforge.net/projects/wxpython/), Perl (wxPerl52
http://wxperl.sourceforge.net/), Ruby (wxRuby53
http://wxruby.rubyforge.org/wiki/wiki.pl), C (wxC54
http://wxc.sourceforge.net/), .NET (wx.NET55
http://wxnet.sourceforge.net/), Java (wx4j56
http://wx4j.sourceforge.net/) and JavaScript (wxJavaScript57
http://www.wxjavascript.net/ and its successor GLUEScript58
http://gluescript.sourceforge.net/).

wxAccessible is a class that allows wxWidgets applications to return accessibility information to assistive technologies. In version 2.8.8, only MSAA is supported by this class59
wxWidgets documentation: wxAccessible: http://docs.wxwidgets.org/2.8.8/wx_wxaccessible.html.
Few documents on building accessible applications with wxWidgets are available:

text:list-item.text:p: “Building Accessible Applications”: http://www.wxwindows.org/docs/technote/wxaccesstips.htm,
Julian Smart: “Accessibility in wxWidgets” (February 2003): http://www.wxwindows.org/docs/access.htm.

office:text.text:p:
AxTk is an open-source accessibility toolkit for wxWidgets. AxTk is cross-platform and includes text-to-speech classes with the ability to drive SAPI 5, Apple Speech Synthesis Manager, eSpeak, and Cepstral60
Julian Smart: “Announcing AxTk – an accessibility toolkit for wxWidgets”, 5 May 2008: http://www.speechcomputing.com/node/2554. .

text:list-item.text:p: AxTk project site: http://code.google.com/p/axtk/;
AxTk User Manual: http://www.anthemion.co.uk/axtk/html/index.html.

office:text.text:h: Interfaces, Classes and Roles: Concordance Table
office:text.text:p: The table in this section provides a mapping between 5 accessibility APIs and ARIA. The column for IAccessible2 (IA2) also lists roles in Microsoft Active Accessibility (MSAA) where necessary. The table does not cover WAI-ARIA’s states and properties; section 3.5 (“State and Property Mapping”) of the WAI-ARIA User Agent Implementation Guide (Leventhal & Cooper, 2009).

Note: Section 6.3.5 of Deliverable D4.1.1 contains a concordance table for the accessibility APIs in Blackberry, iPhone and Android: table 20 compares UI component roles, table 21 compares UI component states, table 22 compares UI component properties, and table 23 compares events to AT.
Legend:

text:list-item.text:p: If = interface
Cl = Class
Ob = Object

(in AtkObject) = listed in AtkObject61
http://library.gnome.org/devel/atk/stable/AtkObject.html#AtkRole

† = listed in ATK 1.26.0 Library62
http://library.gnome.org/devel/atk/stable/
Notes followed by “[ARIA]” are copied from or based on WAI-ARIA (Craig et al, 2009).
Notes followed by “[ATK]” are copied from or based on GNOME ATK documentation.
Notes followed by “[IA2]” are copied from or based on the IAccessible2 API documentation.

Notes followed by “[CARBON]” are copied from or based on the Carbon Accessibility Reference at http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Accessibility/Reference/AccessibilityCarbonRef/Reference/reference.html.Note that role strings are listed at http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Accessibility/Reference/AccessibilityCarbonRef/Reference/reference.html#//apple_ref/doc/constant_group/Rolesand subrole strings athttp://developer.apple.com/documentation/Accessibility/Reference/AccessibilityCarbonRef/Reference/reference.html#//apple_ref/doc/constant_group/Subroles.

Notes followed by “[COCOA]” are copied from or based on the NSAccessibility Protocol Reference at http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Cocoa/Reference/ApplicationKit/Protocols/NSAccessibility_Protocol/Reference/Reference.html.
Notes followed by “[JAAPI]” are copied from or based on the Java Accessibility API documentation at http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/javax/accessibility/package-summary.html.
Notes followed by “[MSAA]” are copied from or based on the documentation for MSAA roles at http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd373608(VS.85).aspx.

office:text.text:p: Table 1: Interfaces, Classes and Roles: Concordance Table

table:table-cell.text:p:
If IUIAutomation63
Microsoft Developer Network (MSDN) Library: IUIAutomation Interface: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd319456(VS.85).aspx.
(HIAccessibility.h and other parts of the Carbon Accessibility API; NSAccessibility.h and other parts of NSAccessibility in Cocoa.)

Cl AtkObject†64
“The base object class for the Accessibility Toolkit API.” http://library.gnome.org/devel/atk/stable/AtkObject.html.

If IUIAutomationElement65
Microsoft Developer Network (MSDN) Library: IUIAutomationElement Interface: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd319271(VS.85).aspx.
Represents the minimum information that accessible objects should return. This set of information is not the same in every API.
The object represents a keyboard shortcut field that allows the user to enter a combination or sequence of keystrokes. [MSAA]
A label which represents an accelerator. [ATK]
Interface for any object that user can activate or interact with.
Implemented by all UI elements that are rendered on the screen.
Dialogue window with an alert message.
(A role, apparently different from the state ‛animated’.)

The object represents an animation control whose content changes over time, such as a control that displays a series of bitmap frames. Animation controls are displayed when files are copied or when some other time-consuming task is performed. [MSAA]
See also supportsAutocompletion in the table for states and properties.

IA2_ROLE_EMBEDDED_OBJECT66
On the Microsoft Windows platform, this normally refers to Object Linking and Embedding (OLE).

application (role)67
The WAI-ARIA 1.0 User Agent Implementation Guide (24 February 2009) does not map its application role to roles with the same name in the other accessibility APIs but to ATK_ROLE_EMBEDDED. See http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-implementation/. A WAI-ARIA application is “content” embedded in a user agent, which is itself an application that needs to implement the accessibility interface of the platform on which it is deployed.
Application embedded in content in another application. / Embedded (OLE) object. [IA2]
A window border. The entire border is represented by a single object rather than by separate objects for each side. [MSAA]
Has boolean value indicating whether a progress is completed or not. (Asynchronous according to Carbon.)
An accessibility object that displays column-based, hierarchically structured data, such as the column view in a Finder window. [CARBON]

Button Role68
Has the following subroles: “Close Button”, “Minimize Button”, “Zoom Button”, “Toolbar Button”, “Increment Arrow”, “Decrement Arrow”, “Increment Page”, “Decrement Page”, “Sort Button”: http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Accessibility/Conceptual/AccessibilityMacOSX/OSXAXRoleReference/OSXAXRoleReference.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40001078-CH211-CACDEHBG. :

kAXButtonRole [CARBON]69
Subroles in Carbon: kAXCloseButtonSubrole, kAXMinimizeButtonSubrole, kAXZoomButtonSubrole, kAXToolbarButtonSubrole, kAXIncrementArrowSubrole, kAXDecrementArrowSubrole, kAXIncrementPageSubrole, kAXDecrementPageSubrole, kAXSortButtonSubrole., NSAccessibilityButtonRole70
Subroles in Cocoa: NSAccessibilityCloseButtonSubrole, NSAccessibilityDecrementArrowSubrole, NSAccessibilityDecrementPageSubrole, NSAccessibilityIncrementArrowSubrole, NSAccessibilityIncrementPageSubrole, NSAccessibilityMinimizeButtonSubrole, NSAccessibilityToolbarButtonSubrole, NSAccessibilityZoomButtonSubrole. , NSAccessibilitySortButtonRole [COCOA]
Features may include name, pressed/unpressed state, enabled, focused, etcetera.
Displays a calendar and allows user to select a date; see also date editor.
The object represents a cartoon-like graphic object, such as Microsoft Office Assistant, which is displayed to provide help to users of an application. (MSAA)

The object is a graphical depiction of quantitative data. It may contain multiple subelements whose attributes and/or description may be queried to obtain both the quantitative data and information about how the data is being presented. The LABELLED_BY relation is particularly important in interpreting objects of this type, as is the accessible-description property. [ATK]
(The timer role is not a true match.)

Apple: “A small rectangular or square control used to apply a color selection. The color of the control indicates the currently selected color.”71
Apple Human Interface Guidelines: Glossary: http://developer.apple.com/documentation/UserExperience/Conceptual/AppleHIGuidelines/XHIGGlossary/XHIGGlossary.html.
Header for a column of data. [ATK] See also table column header
Combines drop-down list with editable field.
The object represents an indicator, such as a pointer graphic, that points to the current item. [MSAA]
Allow a user to edit a date; see also calendar.
An iconified internal frame in a DESKTOP_PANE. [JAAPI]
A graphical image that is used to diagram data. (MSAA)
An object whose purpose is to allow a user to set a value. [ATK] (Unlike a slider, it does not have a bounded range.)
Application window that prompts the user for input.

Disclosure Triangle Role72
“An accessibility object of the disclosure triangle role supports the following action: Press. When the press action is performed, the disclosure triangle changes state (from open to closed or from closed to open).” http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Accessibility/Conceptual/AccessibilityMacOSX/OSXAXRoleReference/OSXAXRoleReference.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40001078-CH211-DontLinkElementID_13:

Triangular button (NSButton in Cocoa) used to hide or show information. The triangle points to the right when closed and points down when open.73
See “Disclosure Triangles and Window Resizing” on CocoaRocket: http://www.cocoarocket.com/articles/disclosureTriangles.html.
kAXDockItemRole, kAXApplicationDockItemSubrole, kAXDocumentDockItemSubrole, kAXFolderDockItemSubrole, kAXURLDockItemSubrole, kAXDockExtraDockItemSubrole & kAXTrashDockItemSubrole [CARBON]
See also “iconified” in table for properties, states and relations.

Child window that slides out from a parent window and that contains controls that are tightly linked to the controls in its parent window.74
See “Drawers” in the Apple Human Interface Guidelines: http://developer.apple.com/documentation/UserExperience/Conceptual/AppleHIGuidelines/XHIGWindows/XHIGWindows.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/20000961-BACEFIJH. See also Michael Gemar: “What’s up with Steve’s drawers?” (MacEdition, 30 January 2001): http://old.macedition.com/op/op_20010130.shtml.
Object used for drawing custom user interface elements. [ATK]
Region or frame containing document content.
Object acting as a formula for calculating a value. [JAAPI] / Editable text object in a toolbar. [IA2]
Endnote at the end of a chapter or a section.
Not a valid role, used for finding end of the enumeration. [ATK]

(java.awt.FileDialog & javax.swing.JFileChooser75
This class is not to be confused with the classes in package javax.swing.filechooser, which are used by JFileChooser. implement If Accessible);
An object that fills up space in a user interface. [JAAPI]

See also the ARIA Subteam Public Meeting Minutes (31 March 2008) and the subsequent thread76
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/wai-xtech/2008Mar/0053.html. .
A top level window with a title bar, border, menu bar, etc. [JAAPI]
Special mouse pointer that allows a user to manipulate user interface elements such as windows. [MSAA]

Cl AtkGObjectAccessible†77
“This object class is derived from AtkObject and can be used as a basis implementing accessible objects.” http://library.gnome.org/devel/atk/stable/AtkGObjectAccessible.html
A grow control. [CARBON], Window’s grow (resize) area [COCOA]
Possibly with level indication, like h1, h2 etcetera in HTML.
The object displays a Help topic in the form of a ToolTip or Help balloon. [MSAA] See also tooltip.

Ob Hyperlink†; ATK_ROLE_LINK78
According to http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-wai-aria-implementation-20090224/; there is a separate object AtkHyperlink: http://library.gnome.org/devel/atk/stable/AtkHyperlink.html. (in AtkObject)

NSAccessibilityLinkRole [COCOA]79
Mapping in the WAI-ARIA 1.0 User Agent Implementation Guide (24 February 2009): http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-implementation/. The document “Roles and Associated Attributes” in Apple's Accessibility Overview does not list this role: http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Accessibility/Conceptual/AccessibilityMacOSX/OSXAXIntro/OSXAXintro.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40001078-CH205-BABGJCGG
A small fixed size picture, typically used to decorate components. [JAAPI]
(An object that displays) an image or a container of elements that form an image.

(See Java Input Method Framework Technology80
JavaTM Input Method Framework Technology: http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/technotes/guides/imf/index.html. This document states that: “The Swing text components in the Java 2 platform are by default active clients of the input method framework.”The Swing text components (javax.swing.text.JTextComponent) implement javax.accessibility.Accessible.See also Naoto Sato: “Using Input Methods on the Java Platform”: http://java.sun.com/products/jfc/tsc/articles/InputMethod/inputmethod.html. )
Object that allows composition or input of characters not found on the keyboard (Chinese etcetera).
A frame-like object that is clipped by a desktop pane. [JAAPI]
The object represents an edit control that is designed for an Internet Protocol (IP) address. The edit control is divided into sections, each for a specific part of the IP address. [MSAA]

NSAccessibilityTitleAttribute81
“Title of element, such as button text (NSString)” NSAccessibility Protocol Reference: http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Cocoa/Reference/ApplicationKit/Protocols/NSAccessibility_Protocol/Reference/Reference.html. / through method accessibilityActionNames ? [COCOA]
Accessible name for an element or object.

List Role: NSAccessibilityListRole [COCOA] (?)82
The WAI-ARIA 1.0 User Agent Implementation Guide (24 February 2009) does not map NSAccessibilityListRole to its list role but to its listbox role. http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-implementation/
The object represents a link to something else. This object might look like text or a graphic, but it acts like a button. [MSAA] See also hyperlink.

ATK_ROLE_LIST (in AtkObject) 83
http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-wai-aria-implementation-20090224/ adds: 'Special case: if a "listbox" has a parent or is owned by (via aria-owns) a "combobox", it should be exposed with ATK_ROLE_MENU.'
List from which user can select one or more items.
Item in a list, listbox or directory. [ARIA]

ATK_ROLE_PANE84
According to http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-wai-aria-implementation-20090224/; not in listed in http://library.gnome.org/devel/atk/stable/ix01.html, which lists several other types of panes.

The outer view that represents the entire contents, including the view through the matte hole, the contents hidden by the matte frame, and the resizing and repositioning controls. An example of an object with a matte role is the iChat icon scaling window. [CARBON]

ATK_ROLE_MENU85
http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-wai-aria-implementation-20090224/ adds: ' These objects should not be exposed for a submenu if there is a parent menu item spawning the submenu' (in AtkObject)
Menu Role: kAXMenuRole [CARBON], Menu Bar Item Role: kAXMenuBarItemRole [CARBON], NSAccessibilityMenuRole [COCOA]
An object usually found inside a menu bar that contains a list of actions the user can choose from. [ATK] See also popup menu.

kAXMenuBarRole [CARBON], NSAccessibilityMenuBarRole [COCOA], Group Role86
The WAI-ARIA 1.0 User Agent Implementation Guide (24 February 2009) does not map its menubar role to Apple's “Menu Bar Role” but to the “Group Role”. http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-implementation/

ATK_ROLE_MENU_ITEM (in AtkObject)87
http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-wai-aria-implementation-20090224/ adds: 'If aria-checked is not undefined, support object attribute "checkable"="true".'

Menu Item Role (if parent has menu rule): kAXMenuItemRole [CARBON], NSAccessibilityMenuItemRole [COCOA], Menu Button Role (if parent has group role)88
According to http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-wai-aria-implementation-20090224/.
Icon or button with a pull-down menu.

ATK_ROLE_CHECK_MENU_ITEM (in AtkObject) + object attribute checkable="true"89
According to http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-wai-aria-implementation-20090224/.
Menu item that is a checkbox.

ATK_ROLE_RADIO_MENU_ITEM (in AtkObject) + object attribute checkable="true"90
According to http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-wai-aria-implementation-20090224/.
Menu item that is a radio button.
Position of a pointing device. See also text cursor.
Embedded note that is not visible until activated. [IA2] / Section whose content is parenthetic or ancillary to the main content of the resource. [ARIA]

Ob AtkNoOpObject†91
“An AtkObject which purports to implement all ATK interfaces.” http://library.gnome.org/devel/atk/stable/AtkNoOpObject.html.

Cl AtkNoOpObjectFactory†92
“The AtkObjectFactory which creates an AtkNoOpObject.” http://library.gnome.org/devel/atk/stable/AtkNoOpObjectFactory.html.

Cl AtkObjectFactory†93
“The base object class for a factory used to create accessible objects for objects of a specific GType.” http://library.gnome.org/devel/atk/stable/AtkObjectFactory.html.

Menu Item Role (if parent has menu role), Static Text Role (if parent has listbox role)94
According to http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-wai-aria-implementation-20090224/.
Selectable item in a select list, such as a combobox, listbox, menu, radiogroup or tree. [ARIA]
An accessibility object that displays row-based, hierarchically structured data, such as the list view in a Finder window.[CARBON]
(Refer to containing markup language; the roles document and article or no exact matches.)
An object representing a page of document content. It is used in documents which are accessed by the user on a page by page basis. [IA2]
Container to create a (virtual) desktop; supports internal frames.
A pane that allows the user to navigate through and select the contents of a directory. [IA2]
(Some Swing componets have a getGlassPane method.)
Primarily for use inside dialogues (message, confirmation, input, options).
Has other types of panes as its children.
For displaying several panels at the same time; usually has a divider that can be manipulated.

“A view that groups together two or more subviews, such as list or column views. A split view includes one or more splitter bars to adjust the relative sizes of the subviews.”95
“Split view” in: Apple Human Interface Guidelines: Glossary: http://developer.apple.com/documentation/UserExperience/Conceptual/AppleHIGuidelines/XHIGGlossary/XHIGGlossary.html.
A temporary window that is usually used to offer the user a list of choices, and then hides when the user selects one of those choices. [ATK] See also menu.

(IA2_ROLE_REDUNDANT_OBJECT)97
“An object which is redundant with another object in the accessible hierarchy. ATs typically ignore objects with this role.” http://a11y.org/a11yspecs/ia2/docs/html/_accessible_role_8idl.html#e37ff81431ee3762a5d41a2cb909108d. / MSAA: do not expose unless focusable
accessibilityIsIgnored returns “YES” [COCOA]; HIObjectIsAccessibilityIgnored returns “true” (default value for custom UI) [CARBON]
For purely presentational or decorative objects which can be ignored by AT.
The display of running applications (processes) that appears when a user presses Command-Tab. [CARBON]

ATK_ROLE_PANE98
According to http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-wai-aria-implementation-20090224/; not in listed in http://library.gnome.org/devel/atk/stable/ix01.html

ATK_ROLE_PANE99
According to http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-wai-aria-implementation-20090224/; not in listed in http://library.gnome.org/devel/atk/stable/ix01.html

Ob AtkRelation†100
For the list of relations, see http://library.gnome.org/devel/atk/stable/AtkRelation.html.

If AccessibleRelation101
For the list of relations, see http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/javax/accessibility/AccessibleRelation.html.
Relations between objects on the screen.
Row of cells in table or grid. See also table row.
Header for a row of data. [ATK] See also table row header.
Such as those used in word processors (for tab stops etc.)
Mechanism for determining what the currently selected items or children are.
Blank area of the screen on which an application can draw and from which it can manage user input events.
Object with graphical representation used to represent content on draw pages. [IA2]

“A dialog attached to a specific window, ensuring that the user never loses track of which window the dialog belongs to. A Print dialog is an example of a sheet. See also document-modal dialog.”103
“Sheet” in “Apple Human Interface Guidelines: Glossary: http://developer.apple.com/documentation/UserExperience/Conceptual/AppleHIGuidelines/XHIGGlossary/XHIGGlossary.html.
Input where the user selects a value from a bounded range. See also time line.

Value Indicator Role104
The Value Indicator Role is more generic than the spin button role. The document “Roles and Associated Attributes” states: “An accessibility object of the value indicator role generally represents the scroller in a scroll bar or the thumb of a slider.” http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Accessibility/Conceptual/AccessibilityMacOSX/OSXAXRoleReference/OSXAXRoleReference.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40001078-CH211-DontLinkElementID_46 : kAXValueIndicatorRole [CARBON], NSAccessibilityValueIndicatorRole [COCOA], Incrementor Role105
“An accessibility object of the incrementor role represents the stepper control (the little arrows)”. http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Accessibility/Conceptual/AccessibilityMacOSX/OSXAXRoleReference/OSXAXRoleReference.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40001078-CH211-DontLinkElementID_18 Note: the WAI-ARIA 1.0 User Agent Implementation Guide (24 February 2009) maps its spinbutton role to Apple's Progress Indicator Role.: kAXIncrementorRole [CARBON], NSAccessibilityIncrementorRole [COCOA]
Input where the user selects a value (usually integer or floating point) from a range. In Carbon, an incrementor is a “stepper control” [CARBON].
The object represents a button on a toolbar that has a drop-down list icon that is directly adjacent to the button. [MSAA]

A splitter bar control. [CARBON] “A control for dividing a window into resizable sections.”106
“Splitter bar” in: Apple Human Interface Guidelines: Glossary: http://developer.apple.com/documentation/UserExperience/Conceptual/AppleHIGuidelines/XHIGGlossary/XHIGGlossary.html.
Class, interface or enumeration that contains a list of roles for UI components.
busy, checked, disabled, dropeffect, expanded, hidden, invalid, pressed, selected (states)
See separate table for states and relations.
Class, interface or enumeration that contains a list of states for UI components.

ATK_ROLE_PAGE_TAB (in AtkObject)107
http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-wai-aria-implementation-20090224/ adds: 'Expose SELECTED state if focus is inside tabpanel associated with aria-labelledby.'

kAXTabGroupRole [CARBON], NSAccessibilityTabGroupRole [COCOA])108
The WAI-ARIA 1.0 User Agent Implementation Guide (24 February 2009) does not map its tablist role to anything in NSAccessibility. http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-implementation/
An object that presents a series of panels (or page tabs), one at a time, through some mechanism provided by the object. [JAAPI]

tabpanel (role)109
The WAI-ARIA 1.0 User Agent Implementation Guide (24 February 2009) maps its tabpanel role to ATK_ROLE_SCROLL_PANE. http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-implementation/
An accessibility object that displays data managed by scrolling controls.[CARBON]

A system-generated dialog window that floats on the top layer, regardless of which application is frontmost. Use this subrole only when a dialog or alert applies to the system as a whole, such as a shutdown dialog. [CARBON]110
Note that Carbon also defines a “kAXSystemFloatingWindowSubrole” (see “window” row).
A system sound associated with a system event.

If AccessibleTable (IA2); ROLE_SYSTEM_TABLE (MSAA)111
See also “Exposing Data Tables through Microsoft Active Accessibility” (April 2002): http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms971325.aspx.

kAXTableRole [CARBON], NSAccessibilityTableRole [COCOA], NSAccessibilityGridRole112
“NSAccessibilityGridRole is a role that should be used for user interfaces like thumbnails and media browsers that present a grid of items. The children of a grid are ordered. A grid is like an accessibility list with the addition of three new attributes: NSAccessibilityRowCountAttribute and NSAccessibilityColumnCountAttribute which return the number of rows and columns in the grid, respectively and NSAccessibilityOrderedByRowAttribute which returns a boolean number value indicating whether the children are ordered row major, or column major.” Mac OS X Leopard Developer Release Notes – Cocoa Application Framework (2007): http://developer.apple.com/releasenotes/Cocoa/AppKit.html#Accessibility. [COCOA]
A button that expands a grid. [MSAA]
Column of cells in a table.
An object that forms part of a menu system but which can be "undocked" from or "torn off" the menu system to exist as a separate window. [IA2]
An object used as a terminal emulator. [IA2]
Read-only (static) text or selectable text. (Not part of any control according to Carbon.)
ATK_ROLE_ENTRY (in AtkObject) + ATK_STATE_SINGLE_LINE of aria-multiline is not "true"

Text Area Role: kAXTextAreaRole [CARBON], NSAccessibilityTextAreaRole [COCOA], Text Field Role113
The WAI-ARIA 1.0 User Agent Implementation Guide (24 February 2009) maps its textbox role only to the Text Area Role.:
Text field: editable text area in a control or window. [CARBON]

UI object that supports rich text with graphics.114
“A text view object that allows rich text can accommodate graphics or other file attachments embedded in the text. The layout manager treats each graphic as a single (possibly large) “character” and adjusts the text’s line height and glyph placement to accommodate the graphic.” From “Text Attachments” in: “Text Attachment Programming Topics for Cocoa”: http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/TextAttachments/TextAttachments.html.

Subrole of NSAccessibilitySliderRole; for media timelines.115
See “Mac OS X Leopard Developer Release Notes – Cocoa Application Framework”: “NSAccessibilityTimelineSubrole is a subrole of NSAccessibilitySliderRole and should be used for media timelines, such as QuickTime movie or audio and video playback and editing controls. A timeline can have multiple value indicators as children to represent different markers on the timeline - for instance the current time, an in point, and an out point for video editing. If multiple value indicators are present, each should have an accessibility description.” http://developer.apple.com/releasenotes/Cocoa/AppKit.html#Accessibility.

Item that navigates like an outline item. The UP and DOWN ARROW keys are used to navigate through the outline. However, instead of expanding and collapsing when the LEFT and RIGHT ARROW key is pressed, these menus expand or collapse when the SPACEBAR or ENTER key is pressed and the item has focus. [MSAA]
A table or grid whose rows (but usually not columns) can be expanded and collapsed.

ATK_ROLE_LIST_ITEM (in AtkObject) + if aria-checked is not undefined, support object attribute "checkable"="true"116
According to http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-wai-aria-implementation-20090224/.

See “Widget Values” in implementation guide117
The properties arie-valuenow, aria-valuemax and aria-valuemin are meant to be exposed via the AccessibleVlue interface. See “Widget Values” in WAI-ARIA 1.0 User Agent Implementation Guide – W3C Working Draft 24 February 2009: http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-wai-aria-implementation-20090224/#mapping_special_widget-value.

(Attribute NSAccessibilityValueDescriptionAttribute [COCOA]118
See “Mac OS X Leopard Developer Release Notes – Cocoa Application Framework”: “The optional attribute NSAccessibilityValueDescriptionAttribute should be used when the value of an element does not provide enough information for assistive applications. For instance, the sliders in the Energy Saver preference pane represent values that include "1 minute", "1 hour", "2 hours 20 minutes", and "never." The numeric value of the slider does not convey this information, so the optional value description attribute should be used. The string values of the attribute should be localized, lower case, and as brief as possible to convey the information.” http://developer.apple.com/releasenotes/Cocoa/AppKit.html#Accessibility. )
To be implemented by any object that supports a numerical value (e.g. a scroll bar).
An object usually used in a scroll pane. [JAAPI]

kAXWindowRole & kAXStandardWindowSubrole & kAXFloatingWindowSubrole & kAXSystemFloatingWindowSubrole [CARBON], NSAccessibilityWindowRole, NSAccessibilityFloatingWindowSubrole, NSAccessibilityStandardWindowSubrole [COCOA]
Application window, usually without title (depending on platform/API).
The object represents a window's client area. Active Accessibility uses this role as a default if there is a question about the role of a UI element. [MSAA]
Used if an object contains accessible information but its role is not known.
An AWT component, but nothing else is known about it. [JAAPI]
A Swing component, but nothing else is known about it. [JAAPI]

office:text.text:h: WAI-ARIA Roles not Represented in the Concordance Table
office:text.text:p:
The following table contains all WAI-ARIA roles (with the exception of abstract roles) that are not represented in the preceding concordance table. For the definitions of these roles, please refer to section 4.4 (“Definition of Roles”) in the last call working draft of 24 February 2009119
http://www.w3.org/TR/2009/WD-wai-aria-20090224/#roles. .

With the possible exception of “definition”, which is relevant to offline word processing, these roles seem specific to the Web. However, hypertext applications predate the Web and the current accessibility APIs, so most of these could have been useful in the current accessibility APIs. Possibly, there absence in APIs is due to the fact that hypertext systems were not common enough or had fallen from grace by the time the accessibility APIs were designed.
Table 2: WAI-ARIA Roles not Represented in Concordance Table

The section “Role mapping” in the WAI-ARIA User Agent Implementation Guide (Leventhal & Cooper, 2009) points out that the role attribute may indicate more than one role while platform accessibility APIs allow only one or two roles to be exposed, and that some ARIA roles are not traditionally part of accessibility APIs. Consequently, there is not always a perfect match for an ARIA role in a platform accessibility API. In WAI-ARIA, additional roles may serve as backup roles. The “Role mapping” section in the implementation guide defines rules for mapping ARIA roles to a platform API and provides a table that maps ARIA roles to roles in MSAA, IAccessible2, ATK and NSAccessiblity.
