This table does not contain the roles listed above.
office:text.text:h: Properties, States and Relations: Concordance Table
office:text.text:p:
The concordance table in this section provides a mapping of properties, states and relations in the most important accessibility APIs. The two most important starting points for this mapping are the “Guidelines for Writing Accessible GNOME Applications Using GTK+ and the Accessibility Toolkit (ATK)” and the table in the WAI-ARIA User Agent Implementation Guide (Leventhal & Cooper, 2009). When the WAI-ARIA User Agent Implementation Guide provides a mapping to a Mac API, it usually provides a value from the Carbon API, but the browsers Safari120
“Most of the applications you see on Mac OS X and iPhone OS, including Mail and Safari, are Cocoa applications.” From: Apple Developer Connection: “What Is Cocoa?” http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/CocoaFundamentals/WhatIsCocoa/WhatIsCocoa.html. (and other browsers such as Camino121
“Camino® is a Web browser optimized for Mac OS X with a Cocoa user interface, and powerful Gecko layout engine.” From: Mozilla.org: Features Projects: http://www.mozilla.org/projects/. , OmniWeb122
http://www.omnigroup.com/mailman/archive/omniweb-l/2000/005265.html. and Shiira123
“Shiira is a web browser based on Web Kit and writtten in Cocoa”: http://shiira.jp/en.php. ) is a Cocoa application.
Legend:

text:list-item.text:p: Values followed by “[P]” are properties.
Values followed by “[RN]” are relations.
Values followed by “[S]” are states.
Mappings and names in the columns “GNOME ATK” and “IA2 & MSAA” are those listed in the “Guidelines for Writing Accessible GNOME Applications Using GTK+ and the Accessibility Toolkit (ATK)”.
Notes followed by “[ATK]” are copied from the above guidelines.
Notes followed by “[ARIA]” are copied from or based on WAI-ARIA (Craig et al, 2009).
Notes followed by “[ARIAUA]” are copied from or based on the WAI-ARIA User Agent Implementation Guide (Leventhal & Cooper, 2009).

office:text.text:p: Table 3: Properties, States and Relations: Concordance Table

table:table-cell.text:p: A window is currently the active window, or is an active sub-element within a container or table. Includes windows, dialogs, frames, etc.(...)[ATK]
Identifies the currently active descendant of a composite widget. [ARIA]

Object's visual representation is changing or moving rapidly; it is dynamic not static. This state may be applied to an object during an animated 'effect' and be removed from the object once its visual representation becomes static. [ATK]
The object is armed. Usually used on buttons that have been pressed but not yet released, and the mouse pointer is still over the button. [ATK]
Indicates if the assistive technology should present all or part of the changed region to the user when the region is updated. Also see aria-relevant. [ARIA]
Identifies that the target object that is doing the controlling has changed. [JAAPI]
Identifies that the controller for the target object has changed. [JAAPI]
Identifies the element (or elements) whose contents or presence are controlled by the current element. Also see aria-owns. [ARIA]
<Or add as a state or relation enumeration, or an attribute>
User interface object corresponding to this object no longer exists. [ATK]
Identifies the element (or elements) that describes the object. Also see aria-labelledby. [ARIA]
Indicates the effect of a drag-and-drop operation when the dragged object is released on the drop target. [ARIA]
Indicates the EMBEDDED_BY relation between two or more objects has changed. [JAAPI]
Indicates the EMBEDS relation between two or more objects has changed. [JAAPI]
Object is not grayed out and can be interacted with if sensitive. [ATK]
The children items of this object that provide progressive disclosure, like trees and drop-down lists, can be showing and visible (expanded) versus hidden (collapsed). [ATK]
Indicates the FLOWS_FROM relation between two objects has changed. [JAAPI]
Identifies the next element (or elements) in the recommended reading order of content, overriding the general default to read in document source order. [ARIA]
Indicates the FLOWS_TO relation between two objects has changed. [JAAPI]
Indicates an element's "grabbed" state in a drag-and-drop operation. [ARIA]
Use ATK_RELATION_POPUP_FOR to point to the parent of the popup.
Use ATK_ROLE_MENU to indicate a menu item has a submenu.
Object has an associated tooltip. Tooltip text should be accessible description. [ATK]
Orientation of this object is horizontal. [ATK]
Object's appearance has changed for a mouseover. [ATK]
Object is minimized and represented only by an icon. [ATK] See also “dock item” role.
aria-invalid [S] (value is not false or undefined)
This object has indicated an error condition due to failure of input validation. For instance, a form control may acquire this state in response to invalid or malformed user input. [ATK]
Object is in an invalid state.
The object is hidden, whether on-screen or off-screen. [ATK]
Defines a string value that labels the current element. Also see aria-labelledby. [ARIA]
Identifies that the target group for a label has changed. [JAAPI]

labelledBy [P]124
“Labelled” is spelled with two l’s in GNOME ATK and WAI-ARIA, but with one l in Java and IAccessible2.
Identifies the element (or elements) that labels the current element. Also see aria-label and aria-describedby. [ARIA]
Identifies that the objects that are doing the labeling have changed. [JAAPI]
Defines the hierarchical level of an element within a structure. [ARIA]

? NSAccessibilityLinkedUIElementsAttribute125
“Elements corresponding to each other (NSArray)” NSAccessibility Protocol Reference: http://developer.apple.com/documentation/Cocoa/Reference/ApplicationKit/Protocols/NSAccessibility_Protocol/Reference/Reference.html. [COCOA]
The object links to another object. [ATK]
Indicates that "active-descendant-changed" event is sent when children become 'active' (i.e. are selected or navigated to onscreen). (...) [ATK]
Object has a grouping relationship (e.g. “same group as”) to one or more other objects. [ATK]
Identifies that group membership has changed. [JAAPI]

INDETERMINATE [S]126
“Indicates that the object state is indeterminate. An example is selected text that is partially bold and partially not bold. In this case the attributes associated with the selected text are indeterminate.” http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/javax/accessibility/AccessibleState.html#INDETERMINATE.
A checkbox object is in a state other than checked or not checked, such as a tri-state checkbox might be. [ATK]
Something must be done with this object before the user can interact with an object in a different window. [ATK]
Object can be moved or dragged around the screen. [ATK]
Object allows more than one of its children to be selected at the same time. [ATK]
Indicates an object is a cell in a treetable which is displayed because a cell in the same column is expanded and identifies that cell. [ATK] Not limited to table cells in Java.
Indicates the CHILD_NODE_OF relation between two or more objects has changed. [JAAPI]

Object paints every pixel within its rectangular region. A non-opaque component paints only some of its pixels, allowing the pixels underneath it to "show through". A component that does not fully paint its pixels therefore provides a degree of transparency. [ATK]
Identifies an element (or elements) in order to define a visual or functional, contextual parent/child relationship among DOM elements (...) [ARIA]
Indicates that an object is a parent window of another object. [ATK]
Indicates the PARENT_WINDOW_OF relation between two or more objects has changed. [JAAPI]
Denotes that the object is a transient window or frame associated with another onscreen object. (...) [ATK]
Identifies an element (or elements) in order to define a visual or functional, contextual parent/child relationship among DOM elements (...) [ARIA]

aria-pressed [S]127
The WAI-ARIA User Agent Implementation Guide (Leventhal & Cooper, 2009) also notes the following: “This property can affect the final role exposed via the platform accessibility API. If not undefined and on a button (ARIA/HTML/XUL), change expose the role as IA2_ROLE_TOGGLE_BUTTON/ATK_ROLE_TOGGLE_BUTTON”.
Used to indicate that a relationship exists, but its type is not specified in the enumeration and must be obtained via a call to getRelationName. (May be specific to AT-SPI.) [ATK]
Indicates the nature of changes within a live region. Also see aria-atomic. [ARIA]
Object can be interactive, although it may currently be read-only or not enabled (grayed out). STATE_SENSITIVE usually accompanies STATE_ENABLED for user-actionable controls, (...) [ATK]
Defines the number of items in the current set of listitems or treeitems. Not required if inferred by the DOM. Also see aria-posinset. [ARIA]
Text object can only contain a single line of text. [ATK]
Indicates if items in a table or grid are sorted in ascending or descending order. [ARIA]
Index associated with this object has changed since the user accessed the object. The information returned for this object may no longer be synchronized with the application state. [ATK]
Object is visually and semantically considered a subwindow of another object, even though it is not the object's child. (...) [ATK]
Indicates the SUBWINDOW_OF relation between two or more objects has changed. [JAAPI]
Object is a tooltip associated with another object. [ATK]
Object is changing or moving rapidly. An assistive technology should not add a property change listener to an object with transient state, as that object will never generate any events. (...) [ATK]
Object is truncated, such as a numerical value in a spreadsheet cell. [ATK]
Object is grayed out and not available at this time. [ATK]
Defines the maximum allowed value for a range widget. [ARIA]
Defines the minimum allowed value for a range widget. [ARIA]
set AXValue and post NSAccessibilityValueChangedNotification if necessary [ARIAUA]
Defines the current value for a range widget. Also see aria-valuetext. [ARIA]
Defines the human readable text equivalent of aria-valuenow for a range widget. [ARIA]
Orientation of this object is vertical. [ATK]
Object is not hidden but may be off-screen. STATE_VISIBLE is no guarantee that the object is actually unobscured on the screen, only that it is 'potentially' visible, (...) [ATK]

office:text.text:h: Accessibility Requirements Not Reflected in APIs
office:text.text:p: Some types of accessibility requirements and features are not “visible” in accessibility APIs, for example:

text:list-item.text:p: keyboard access,
magnification and zooming,
sufficient contrast in default “theme” of user interface,
text resizing (independent of magnification or zooming),
support for themes for high contrast or inheritance (by an application) of the platform's colour scheme and font properties,
absence or avoidance of blinking elements and flashing on the screen,
absence or avoidance of repetitive sounds,
consistency in menus (navigation menus, names of functions in other menus) and other user interface controls (naming of links and buttons),

availability of shortcuts (keyboard shortcuts for functions128
See java.awt.MenuShortcut: http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/awt/MenuShortcut.html. Move to mapping table?, skiplinks),
availability of alternatives for audio and video (captions, transcripts, audio description),
interface with speech recognition software for driving applications by speech instead of other input devices,
certain features that are useful for users with dyslexia, e.g. text highlighting during speech synthesis,
identification or notification of default language and language changes in content,
usability on a small screen,
usability over a slow internet connection.

office:text.text:p: For software that produces content, there are additional requirements, for example:

text:list-item.text:p: support for accessible authoring practices,
promoting accessibility in help and documentation.

office:text.text:p:
Editorial Note: Other requirements for this type of tool are also defined in the W3C Authoring Tool Accessibility Guidelines (ATAG)129
Jutta Treviranus et al, eds: “Authoring Tool Accessibility Guidelines 1.0 - W3C Recommendation 3 February 2000” http://www.w3.org/TR/ATAG10/ Jutta Treviranus et al, eds: “Authoring Tool Accessibility Guidelines 2.0 - W3C Working Draft 17 February 2009” http://www.w3.org/TR/ATAG20/ .

StickyKeys is designed for people who cannot use both hands, or who use a dowel or stick to type. StickyKeys allows individuals to press key combinations (e.g. CTRL-ALT-DEL) sequentially rather than having to hold them all down together. StickyKeys works with those keys defined as "modifier" keys, such as the Shift, Alt and Control keys. When enabled, this function causes modifier keys to "stick" until they are either manually released, or until a keystroke combination is complete. Usually the StickyKeys status is shown on-screen at the user’s option.

StickyKeys usually is turned on from the keyboard by pressing the Shift key 5 times with no intervening key presses or mouse clicks . A confirmation dialogue is recommended for keyboard activation of this feature, though the user should be able to turn this dialogue off. Audible and visual indicators are recommended when the feature is turned on or off.

SlowKeys is designed for users who have extra, uncontrolled movements that cause them to strike surrounding keys unintentionally when typing, it introduces a minimum time that the keys have to be held for.. SlowKeys causes the keyboard to ignore all keys that are bumped or pressed briefly. Keystrokes are accepted only if keys are held down for a user specifiable period of time. An optional beep on key acceptance is recomended.

SlowKeys usually is turned on from the keyboard by holding the right shift key down for 8 seconds (if keyboard activation of this feature has been enabled). A confirmation dialogue is recommended for keyboard activation of this feature, though the user should be able to turn this dialogue off. Audible and visual indicators are recommended when the feature is turned on or off.

BounceKeys is designed for users with tremor that causes them to inadvertently strike a key extra times when pressing or releasing the key. BounceKeys only accepts a single keystroke at a time from a key. Once a key is released it will not accept another stroke of the same key until a (user settable) period of time has passed. BounceKeys has no effect on how quickly a person can type a different key.

BounceKeys usually is turned on from the keyboard by holding the right shift key down for 8 seconds (if keyboard activation of this feature has been enabled in the control panel). A confirmation dialogue is recommended for keyboard activation of this feature, though the user should be able to turn this dialogue off. Audible and visual indicators are recommended when the feature is turned on or off.

A name sometime used for the BounceKeys and SlowKeys features packaged together. It is acceptable to make these two features be mutually exclusive, however they can both be active at the same time. It can also include a delay where no key will be accepted until a set time since the last key was pressed, like Bouncekeys but for all keys.

MouseKeys is designed for users who cannot use a mouse accurately (or at all) because of physical capability. MouseKeys allows the individual to use the keys on the numeric keypad to control the mouse cursor on screen and to operate the mouse buttons.

MouseKeys may be activated from the keyboard by using the LeftShift-LeftAlt-NumLock key combination. Once MouseKeys is turned On the NumLock key can be used to switch the keypad back and forth between MouseKeys operation and one of the other two standard modes of keypad operation (number pad or key navigation). It is recommended that there be an option for showing MouseKeys status on screen.

RepeatKeys is designed to allow use of computers by people who cannot move quickly enough when pressing keys to keep them from auto-repeating. The facility to adjust repeat onset, repeat rate and to turn auto-repeat off are usually included as part of most keyboard control panels. If these functions are not included, RepeatKeys provides them. RepeatKeys also ensures that the repeat delay and repeat interval can be set long enough for users who do not have quick response (if the maximum value for either of the regular key repeat settings are not long enough).

ToggleKeys is a feature for users who cannot see the visual keyboard status indicators for locking (toggle) keys such as CapsLock, ScrollLock, NumLock, etc. ToggleKeys provides an auditory signal, such as a high beep, to alert the user that a toggle key such as the CapsLock has been locked, and a separate signal, such as a low beep, to alert the user that a toggle key has been unlocked.

A well-designed keyboard UI is an important aspect of software accessibility. It enables users who are blind or who have certain motor disabilities to navigate an application and interact with its features. Such users may be unable to operate a mouse, and may rely on assistive technologies — such as keyboard enhancement tools, on-screen keyboards, screen enlargers, screen readers, and voice input utilities — all of which depend on an application's keyboard UI.

Many assistive technologies use the keyboard UI programmatically, even if users are not using a standard keyboard input device. Although some assistive technologies may have custom keyboard shortcuts that can make an operation easier, consistency and standardization in keyboard UI design — for assistive technologies and for all aspects of accessibility — are critical to avoid confusing users.

In the previous section, accessibility options have been reviewed that enhance keyboard functionality, such as StickyKeys, FilterKeys, ToggleKeys, and MouseKeys. These tools can help users to operate applications with the keyboard. However, they do not replace the accessibility provided by a well-designed keyboard UI. Well-designed applications include two basic requirements:

text:list-item.text:p: They must be usable even when the keyboard is the sole input device.
They must also be functional and user-friendly.

office:text.text:p: To design an effective keyboard UI, the following design rules should be used:

text:list-item.text:p: Provide keyboard access to all features, and document the keyboard interface.

It is recommended that the keyboard be able to perform the same tasks as a mouse device. Document the keyboard UI in the product manual and through online Help. Be sure that the input focus location (the point at which input is being directed in the UI) is provided programmatically as well as visually.
Keep keyboard navigation quick and easy.

Provide simple keyboard navigation methods. Keyboard navigation methods should be as straightforward as mouse navigation methods. Provide programmable, customizable shortcut methods for common and repetitive tasks.
Avoid unexpected keyboard UI changes.
The keystrokes required for a task should not change unexpectedly. For example, the underlined access key for a command should be the same regardless of selection or other modal states.
Provide a consistent keyboard navigation model.
Applications need to be consistent with basic keyboard navigation models to avoid system problems. Avoid unexpected shifts in input focus.
Provide consistent keyboard shortcuts.

A consistent keyboard UI between applications helps users to learn and interact with new applications. An application must not affect any system-wide shortcut keys (a key or a combination of keys used to perform a command), such as the logo key that opens the Start menu. An application must also follow commonly recognized shortcut key assignments, such as CTRL+C for Copy and CTRL+Z for Undo.

However, this does not mean that all shortcut keys need to be standardized or that applications must always be forced to support the same shortcut keys. For example, not all applications need to support CTRL+P for printing.
Avoid simultaneous multiple key input.

Applications should not require users to press multiple keys simultaneously, except for the modifier keys SHIFT, CTRL, ALT, and the logo key. The StickyKeys accessibility feature can simulate key combinations by allowing users to press keys in a sequential order.
Unique Original Equipment Manufacturer (OEM) function keys, such as the Fn key on laptop computer keyboards, are not supported as modifiers.
Avoid interfering with desktop-supported accessibility options or emulated input devices.

An application cannot interfere with desktop-supported keyboard and mouse accessibility options, such as StickyKeys, FilterKeys, ToggleKeys, and MouseKeys. Input from emulated input devices must be the same as for standard devices. Applications must be able to take input from keyboard or mouse emulated devices, such as with an on-screen keyboard or SerialKeys device.

office:text.text:p: The keyboard focus (sometimes called "input focus") designates the active window or component where the user's next keystrokes will take effect. Focus typically moves when users click a component with a pointing device or move to the next component using keyboard equivalents. Either way, users designate the window, or component within a window, that receives input. (Many toolbar buttons are exceptions: for instance, a left-alignment button on a toolbar should not take focus away from the text area where the actual work is taking place.)

When a window is first opened, assign initial keyboard focus to the component that would normally be used first. Often, this is the component appearing in the upper-left portion of the window. If keyboard focus is not assigned to a component in the active window, the keyboard navigation and control mechanisms cannot be used. The assignment of initial keyboard focus is especially important for people who use only a keyboard to navigate through your application, for instance, those with visual or mobility impairments and many power users.

screenshots of seven types of Java Swing components: a non-editable combo box, a radio button, a command button, a tabbed pane, a list box, a table and a tree component. Illustration 1: Keyboard focus in Java Swing components indicated by rectangular border
Many components (including command buttons, checkboxes, radio buttons, toggle buttons, list boxes, combo boxes, tabbed panes, editable cells, and tree components) indicate keyboard focus by displaying a rectangular border (blue, in the default color theme).

Keyboard navigation enables users to move keyboard focus from one user interface component to another using the keyboard. Navigation does not necessarily affect the selection and does not, by itself, cause activation. Keyboard activation, on the other hand, enables users to cause an action by using the keyboard.

In general, pressing the Tab key moves focus through the major components; Shift-Tab moves through the components in the reverse direction. Control-Tab and Control-Shift-Tab work in a similar fashion and are necessary when keyboard focus is in an element that accepts tabs, such as a text area or on dialogues with tabbed pages. Arrow keys are often used to move within groups of components, for example, Tab puts focus in a list box and then the arrow keys move focus among the list box items. The Tab key is used to move among checkboxes.

Once an element has focus, pressing the spacebar typically activates its function, such as selecting or deselecting a checkbox. In a list component, pressing Shift-spacebar extends the selection; pressing Control-spacebar toggles the selection state of the current item without affecting any other selections. (Using the up and down arrow keys actually changes the selection in a list component.)

Some components do not need explicit keyboard focus to be operated. For example, users activate the default button in a dialogue box by pressing the Enter or Return key. Similarly, scrollbars can be operated from the keyboard using keys such as Page Up and Page Down if focus is anywhere within the scroll pane.
Keyboard navigation can be useful not only for accessibility purposes but also for power users or users who choose alternative input methods like voice input or touch screens.
To ensure that all application functions are accessible from the keyboard it is recommended to unplug the mouse and testing the application's keyboard operations.
In the following table common keyboard navigation and activation operations are summarized:

text:p.text:span: : Common keyboard navigation and activation operations are summarized in the following table.

table:table-cell.text:p: Move to the next focusable control. Controls that are disabled or invisible cannot receive keyboard focus, nor can controls that do absolutely nothing, like static text or group boxes. Also, grouped controls are treated as a set.
Move to the previous focusable control
Navigates to the next focusable component (works even if the component that previously had focus accepts tabs)
Moves focus left one character or component
Moves focus right one character or component
Moves focus up one line or component
Moves focus down one line or component
Moves up one pane of information
Moves down one pane of information
Moves to the beginning of the data; in a table, moves to the beginning of a row
Moves to the end of the data; in a table, moves to the last cell in a row
Dismisses a menu or dialogue box without changes; cancels a drag-and-drop operation in progress
Activates the component that has keyboard focus

office:text.text:p: In text editing environments adding control to arrow keys moves the focus by word or paragraph. Adding shift will select the navigated span of text.

Keyboard shortcuts are keystroke combinations that activate a menu item from the keyboard even if the menu for that command is not currently displayed. Keyboard shortcuts usually consist of a modifier key and a character key, like Control-Z, plus a few special keys such as F1 and Delete. Unlike mnemonics, keyboard shortcuts do not post menus; rather, they perform the indicated actions directly. Since all keyboard shortcuts are available at all times, you cannot reuse them as you do mnemonics.

To use a keyboard shortcut users typically hold down the Control key (and optionally, an additional modifier key, such as Shift or Alt) and press the character key that is shown after the menu item; in some cases, they press the single key that corresponds to the shortcut, such as the Delete key in the previous figure. Typing a keyboard shortcut has the same effect as choosing the corresponding menu item. For instance, to undo an action, users can either choose the Undo item from the Edit menu or hold down the Control key and press Z.

text:p.text:span: Do not provide a shortcut for all commands. S
pecify keyboard shortcuts for frequently used menu items to provide an alternative to mouse operation.
But all commands should be navigable to by keyboard operation of menus and dialogues by using mnemonics (see below).
isplay keyboard shortcuts using the standard abbreviations for key names (such as Ctrl for the Control key), separated by hyphens.

text:list-item.text:p: Be aware of and use the common shortcuts across platforms. If the application doesn't use a particular command, you can use that common shortcut for some other command. However, if a later version of your application is likely to contain the common command, reserve the shortcut so future users won't have to relearn your shortcuts.
Do not use the Meta key (the Command key on the Macintosh platform) for a keyboard shortcut, except as an alternate for Control. It is not available on some target platforms.

office:text.text:p: The common keyboard shortcuts (in the order of their use in menus) are summarized in the following table. Because each platform has its own standard keyboard shortcuts, ensure that any new keyboard shortcuts that has been created is compatible with existing shortcuts on all your target platforms.
Table 5: Common Keyboard Shortcuts (Organized by Menus)

Mnemonics provide yet another keyboard alternative to the mouse. A mnemonic is an underlined alphanumeric character in a menu title, menu item, or other interface component. It reminds the user how to activate the equivalent command by simultaneously pressing the Alt key and the character key that corresponds to the underlined letter or numeral.
Illustration 2 shows an example of keyboard shortcuts and mnemonics on a typical Edit menu.

draw:text-box.text:p: Edit menu with commands; each command has a shortcut. Menu with 9 commands and their mnemonics shortcuts. For example, Undo has the shortcut Crtl+Z and its mnemonics is U (the first letter is underlined); Redo has the shortcut Ctrl+Y and its mnemonic is R (underlined), etc. Illustration 2: Edit menu with keyboard shortcuts and mnemonics

office:text.text:p: When keyboard focus is not in a text element, the Alt modifier is not always required. Menus are an example. For instance, to choose the Exit command from the File menu, the user can hold down the Alt key and press F to post the File menu, release the Alt key, and then press X.

Unlike keyboard shortcuts, mnemonics can be reused from one context to another. Once users have displayed a menu with a keyboard sequence, the subsequent keypress can activate a command only from that menu. Hence, users can press Alt-F to display the File menu and then type A to activate the Save As command, or press Alt-E to display the Edit menu, and then type A to activate the Select All command.

Mnemonics should be provided for components within the dialogue boxes in the application. In dialogue boxes, users must press a modifier key to activate the associated component. For instance, within a dialogue box, the user might have a mnemonic for the Help button. Once keyboard focus is within the dialogue box, users press Alt and then H to activate the Help button.

text:list-item.text:p: Provide a mnemonic for all menu titles, menu items, and dialogue box components in your application.
Do not associate mnemonics with the default button or the Cancel button in a dialogue box. Use Enter or Return for the default button and Escape for the Cancel button instead.
Choose mnemonics that avoid conflicts within a context. For instance, the letter P should be not used as the mnemonic for both the Print and Page Setup commands in the File menu.
Ensure that the mnemonics associated with menu titles are not reused in any context in which the menus are active.
When mnemonics are assigned, these guidelines should be followed in the specified order.

text:p.text:span: Use common mnemonics as they appear in

text:list-item.text:p: If the mnemonic does not appear in the table of common mnemonics, choose the first letter of the menu item. (For instance, choose J for Justify.)

If the first letter of the menu item conflicts with the mnemonics of other items, choose a prominent consonant. (For instance, the letter S may have already been designated as the mnemonic for the Style command. Therefore, choose the letter Z as the mnemonic for the Size command.)
If the first letter of the menu item and the prominent consonant conflict with those of other menu items, choose a prominent vowel.

text:p.text:span: shows the most common mnemonics organized by the menu in which they usually appear

office:text.text:p: Table 6: Common Mnemonics (Organized by Menu)

table:table-cell.text:p: New, Open, Close, Save, Save As, Page Setup, Print, Exit
Undo, Redo, Cut, Copy, Paste, Delete, Find, Find Again, Select All
Font, Style, Size, Bold, Italic, Underline, Align Left, Align Center, Align Right
Large Icons, Small Icons, List, Details, Sort By, Filter, Zoom In, Zoom Out, Refresh
Contents, Tutorial, Index, Search, About Application

office:text.text:p: An On-Screen Keyboard (frequently abbreviated to OSK) is a visual representation of a standard keyboard that can be installed on any computer. It allows people with mobility impairments to type data by using a pointing device or joystick. An On–Screen Keyboard can also help people who do not know how to type, provided that the OSK keys may contain and output whole words or phrases, typically represented by graphical symbols/images, and/or supports spoken auditory cueing. For this kind of use it is vital that the OSK provides a user-friendly interface for the editing of OSK content (presentation and output – see SAW 5 below).

The flexibility of their visual display combined with audio output makes some OSKs suitable for people with visual impairment as well as physical difficulties. A few OSKs can read keys aloud when the mouse pointer is hovered over them. This feature can help users with cognitive difficulties, including severe cases of dyslexia.
An On-Screen Keyboard needs to have many access options to be able to cope with a wide range of physical needs. Useful access features include:

text:list-item.text:p: Dwell action with an adjustable delay (for users who struggle to use the mouse button)
Single switch access (see animated demonstration - requires Flash)
Two switch access (see animated demonstration - requires Flash)
Row/column scanning (for more efficient scanning)
Advanced scanning options (such as overscan)
Visual accessibility options (resizable keys, changeable colours and fonts)
Audio output (including when scanning with a single switch)

office:text.text:p: All OSKs provide the user access to the letters of the alphabet, numbers, some punctuation and other common keyboard keys. Other feature-rich keyboards offer the facility to make your own 'keys' that can perform much more advanced tasks such as launch a program or even operate environmental control.

Typing on an on-screen keyboard can be slow and some switch users in particular can only produce a few letters a minute. Prediction allows words to be completed automatically and can greatly increase the overall typing rate for slower users. Dasher's prediction is slightly different in that it works letter-by-letter rather than word-by-word.
Most of the OSK available are static. Some of their most common features are

text:list-item.text:p: View an enhanced keyboard that includes the numeric keypad, or a standard keyboard that does not include a numeric keypad.
Display the keyboard with the keys in the standard layout, or in a block layout in which the keys are arranged in rectangular blocks. Block layout is especially useful in scanning mode.
Display the U.S. standard keyboard (101 keys), the universal keyboard (102 keys), or a keyboard (106 keys) with additional Japanese language characters.
Use Click Sound to add an audible click when you select a key.

Screenshot showing the full on-screen keyboard on Windows XP with a querty layout Illustration 3: Windows OSK application
Use Always On Top to keep your keyboard displayed on your screen when you switch programs or windows.
Some OSKs are able to display alternative specialised (possibly macro) keyboards for specialised use and have keyboard designer functionailty (e.g. The Grid 2 and SAW).

office:text.text:p: The main mission of dynamic keyboards is two give the user access to all the functions in the least number of steps. There are two main open source initiatives that give users these most innovative input tools:
GOK

GOK is an on-screen keyboard that provides access to the GNOME desktop via dynamically generated keyboards, and text entry via one of the provided alphanumeric keyboards, or a dynamic keyboard created based on the users current system keyboard driver, or even a user made keyboard.

GOK keyboards are created in two ways. Dynamic keyboards are created (while GOK is running) to provide access to the desktop and application GUIs. Premade keyboards are specified using fairly simple xml (".kbd") files.

GOK allows the creation of new ways of operating the GOK keyboards via xml "access method" files (".xam") files. These files also provide the description of the user interface for the access method's settings. Current access methods include:

text:list-item.text:p: automatic-scanning.xam
dwell-selection.xam
singlekey-automatic-scanning.xam
singlekey-inverse-scanning.xam
directed.xam
inverse-scanning.xam

Screenshot of GOK in Czech with 9 buttons in a three-by-three grid. Illustration 4: GNOME on-screen keyboard (GOK)
direct-selection.xam

office:text.text:p: SAW 5 (Special Access to Windows)

SAW 5 is an example of an advanced and highly tailorable open source dynamic OSK that supports features listed above such as auditory hovering and scanning, graphic symbol/image display, macro programming, integration of word prediction and more. Below are a few examples of the widely varying appearances of different set-ups.

Window Catcher (see above) was designed to show how MSAA and UIAutomation could be used to automatically build on-screen keyboards (called selection sets) for SAW. Currently these are not automatic with SAW itself. WindowCatcher is currently a tool to help designers create SAW selection sets for compliment applications. It would not take a great deal of work to fully incorporate WindowCatcher into SAW so that end-users could request selection sets to be built and then run for 'unknown' or new interfaces.

draw:text-box.text:p: Screenshot of SAW with 44 keys arranged in 4 rows, for a Swedish user Illustration 5: SAW 5: Frequency based keyboard layout with macro keys and links to word list and other layouts.
Screensho of SAW with a dozen buttons, such as Up, Down, Home, Next and Previous. Illustration 6: SAW 5: Web navigation layout.
Screenshot of SAW with the names of musical notes (a, c, d, e, g etc) arranged in a circle around a guitar icon. Illustration 7: SAW 5: Free form music activity layout.
Screenshot of SAW with BLISS symbols (with their Swedish translations) being used to write an e-mail. Illustration 8: SAW 5: Blissymbol display with whole word output to a web based email service.

office:text.text:p: Dasher

Dasher is an information-efficient text-entry interface, driven by natural continuous pointing gestures. Dasher is a competitive text-entry system wherever a full-size keyboard cannot be used, for example,

text:list-item.text:p: When operating a computer one-handed, by joystick, touchscreen, trackball, or mouse;
When operating a computer with zero hands (i.e., by head-mouse or by eye tracker);
On a palmtop computer;
On a wearable computer.

office:text.text:p: The eye-tracking version of Dasher allows an experienced user to write text as fast as normal handwriting - 29 words per minute; using a mouse, experienced users can write at 39 words per minute.

draw:text-box.text:p: Screenshot of Dasher with input suggestions in the right half of the screen and letters chosen by the user in the left half of the screen. Illustration 9: Dasher

office:text.text:h: Theming Support, Text Resizing, Magnification and Zooming
office:text.text:p: The platform (desktop OS, mobile or other type of platform) needs to allow the use of “themes”. A theme is a set of preferences which holds colour schemes, font types, font sizes and other aspects of the GUI’s visible appearance. The UI control panel, Wizard or other application which sets these options needs to be itself accessible. These settings should be stored in a user profile (or roaming profile, these will be discussed in more detail in A1.3.1.) which is automatically loaded when the user logs onto a device. The logging in or start-up procedure needs to remember the last used theme or have some accessible way of displaying required themes on a re-start of the system.
The system cursor (or animated cursor) should always be available to be displayed at the mouse position, and application-specific icons or animations should be optional.

The ability to move user options onto a memory stick and transfer their preferences between machines or over a network is desirable. Workstations with card log-ins, finger print or face recognition can load personal settings. Finally UI profiles and open source templates could be accessed over the internet for use on public facilities in libraries and Internet cafés, but there are security issues to be addressed here.
The documents below discuss theme support on various platforms:

text:list-item.text:p: “Themes” in “Java Look and Feel Design Guidelines”: http://java.sun.com/products/jlf/ed2/book/HIG.Visual.html#64579
“Desktop Appearance Enhancement” in the “GNOME Desktop Accessibility Guide”: http://library.gnome.org/users/gnome-access-guide/stable/themes-0.html.en
Chapter 10: “Personalizing Ubuntu: Getting it just right”. Beginning Ubuntu Linux, Second Edition, Keir Thomas, Apress ISBN13: 978-1-59059-820-7 ISBN10: 1-59059-820-2
Microsoft: “Customize a theme”: http://windows.microsoft.com/en-US/windows/downloads/personalize

office:text.text:p: Options can be set from accessibility/usability control panels, personalisation wizard options or applied from an 'as needed' basis from system tray applications. TTS support should be provided in these set-up systems if the initial UI is not suitable or accessible to the user. Some simple modifiable templates can be provided to give a starting adaptation (for example, Windows XP’s themes) but then the user can modify these.

It is important that all the user preferences can be accesses from a single control panel/wizard/application. The centralisation of preferences should also include those settings for keyboard, sound and others. Systems have suffered in the past from settings that could help users interact with the system being buried in some other part of the system set-up (these settings could still be mirrored in other places.

Applications should always to inherit styles from user preferences. The platform itself needs to expose these settings through an API so that applications running on that platform can implement the preferences in their own GUI. Applications running on the platform need to access this API and apply the theme to their user interface components. There may be limits to the practicality in standard applications and this is where AT takes over – but the limits need to be defined.
Guide and checklists for a number of programming languages are available, for example:

text:list-item.text:p: Human Ability and Accessibility Center: Developer guidelines: Checkpoint 4.3: System settings for high contrast - examples for Java developers: http://www-03.ibm.com/able/guidelines/software/javahicont.html.

office:text.text:p: There should be a mechanism for users to override the current theme, simply and quickly – and similarly revert to the current theme. This may be because of particular needs in certain applications or because a facilitator or helper needs to temporarily have access.

Some applications, especially browsers, provide options to override the default theme, see for example the themes for Mozilla SeaMonkey, the Stylish add-on for Firefox, and the “skins” in Opera. Opera 9 has an “Opera Standard” skin that only partially inherits Windows XP’s settings, while its “Windows Native” fully respects the OS colour scheme.

A RIA is an applications that runs inside another application - the browser – which thereby becomes a sort of “platform”. Some RIAs can be run in other environments, for example Flash on desktops or mobiles. From the point of view of accessibility it should not matter whether an application runs directly on an OS or in a browser. In reality it can make a big difference because of missing keyboard shortcuts, keyboard shortcuts that conflict with those used by the browser, keyboard trapping in applets, no inheritance of colour schemes etcetera. RIAs should inherit the properties of a theme defined in the OS. There are two possible mechanisms:

text:list-item.text:p: the browser exposes the properties through an API and the JavaScript/Flash/Silverlight/... script/applet could pick them up from there.
In RIAs based on JavaScript and Cascading Style Sheets (CSS), the CSS stylesheet(s) can use system colours and system fonts and generate style sheets from the system theme.

office:text.text:p: For system fonts and system colours in CSS see:

text:list-item.text:p: system fonts: http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/fonts.html#x11 (CSS 2.1) and the older http://www.w3.org/TR/1998/REC-CSS2-19980512/fonts.html#x27 (CSS 2);
system colours: http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/ui.html#system-colors (CSS 2.1) and the older http://www.w3.org/TR/1998/REC-CSS2-19980512/ui.html#system-colors (CSS 2)

office:text.text:p:
According to a discussion thread on the W3C’s WAI-XTECH mailing list, mainstream browsers supported these CSS features130
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/w3c-wai-gl/2007OctDec/0115.html.
. CSS system colours and fonts are under-utilised, even in alternative stylesheets provided by web developers and their utilisation often requiring inelegant solutions. For example Dojo can be made to use a high-contrast mode, however, the detection of high-contrast uses a hack:

Whenever you load the base Dijit classes, which happens anytime you use dojo.require to load a Dijit component, Dijit performs a small test:1. It constructs a small red and green bordered box outside of the browser limits. Because of its coordinates, the user will never actually see it.2. Dijit then tests to see whether the actual colors of the box borders are green and red. If they’re not, Dijit takes that to mean its own stylesheet is off.3. Then, exactly like setting the dj_ie and dj_gecko styles, it tags the document with a dijit_a11y class.4. Whenever a component needs an a11y alternate, the Dijit style sheet, dijit.css, has overriding rules with selectors beginning with dijit_a11y. (Quoted from Rawld Gil et al, 2008, p. 440)

draw:text-box.text:p: Windows XP screenshot showing a dialog where the user can choose themes from a drop-down list. Illustration 10: Microsoft Windows theme configuration

office:text.text:p: Within any platform all standard colours should be re-definable. It would be helpful if warnings were given when low contrast colour combinations are selected.

draw:text-box.text:p: Screenshot of a dialog where the user can choose settings related to vision and hearing Illustration 11: Stylistic highlight in Firefox

office:text.text:p: Visible highlighters of keyboard shortcuts should be part of the colour scheme – keyboard shortcut indicators should have a style and colour set and not just be indicated by an underscore. The 'Tab' focus indicator should be configurable for outline thickness and colour and text colour.

The ability to change icon sizes is useful for people with low vision but also for those with motor impairments that make precise pointing and clicking difficult Mouse over – focus given magnification would optimise workspace whilst giving better visibility. For example the Mac OS X Dock uses a magnifier to enlarge the icons at the centre of the scroll.131
See Apple – Accessibility – Mac OS X – Vision: http://www.apple.com/accessibility/macosx/vision.html and Mac 101: Customize the Dock: http://support.apple.com/kb/HT2491.

The capability of substituting pictures for icons adapted to the colour and size preferences of the user, either for visibility or comprehension of their function chooses. At the level of implementation, this would be easier if these images where vector-based instead of pixel-based to give better clarity at larger. The ideal would be to use the Concept Coding Framework l for these images .

Font – size, spacing (vertical and horizontal – leading and kerning) style (type face). Not all Windows fonts respond to theme changes in particular system warning/information dialogues always use their default font.

Mouse cursor or animated cursors should be available in a large style, preferably being able to replace them with vector graphics rather than pixel based images (The current limits in Windows XP is 48 pixels and Apple OS X is 128 pixels. Applications should use those set in the system or at least follow the system size

draw:text-box.text:p: Three Mac OS X screenshots: one with the default theme, one with a greyscale theme and one with a colour inversion theme. Illustration 12: Mac OS X colour theme setting

office:text.text:p: Developers must use defined colours fonts and not impose their own. Users will need to set their own preferences (similar to cascading style sheets) and have them followed system wide. A checking system for colour contrast is desirable, to ensure there is at least a warning of poor contrast is given. A reset to include a B/W, high contrast and/or back to 'factory' settings would be helpful for users who get themselves into unworkable UIs.

Part of a dialog where the user can choose a colour using a colour wheel, a colour grid, RGB values or HSL values. Illustration 13: RGB and HSL colour settings in a Microsoft Windows application
The colour triangle does not contain luminance information For high contrast the two colours need to be a fair distance apart on an axis parallel to a side of have a high luminance difference. A high colour saturations (S) will give higher contrast.

draw:text-box.text:p: sRGB colour triangle shown as a subset of x,y space based on the CIE 1931 colour space Illustration 14: The additive colour triangle (source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Color_triangle)

office:text.text:p: If you have two colours (H1,L1,S1) and (H2,L2,S2), the colour distance will be
There is a complex relationship between the RGB and HSL values for a colour [See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HSL_and_HSV]

Note: WCAG 2 has a “luminosity contrast ratio” algorithm that uses RGB values (see below); and a linked definition of “relative luminance”. CSS defines colours by means of RGB values, so an HSL-based algorithm is not useful to most web developers. WCAG also defines two levels of contrast based on the algorithm, Windows only distinguishes between “high contrast” schemes and the rest.

A discussion of the sRGB colour space is available in: "A Standard Default Color Space for the Internet - sRGB," M. Stokes, M. Anderson, S. Chandrasekar, R. Motta, eds., Version 1.10, November 5, 1996. A copy of this paper is available at http://www.w3.org/Graphics/Color/sRGB.html.
office:text.text:h: Contrast ratios of normal and inverted colour sets
office:text.text:p: When setting colour preferences the contrast of the inverted colour set should also be tested. The actual visibility of given colour combinations is subjective and some combinations that have a low contrast rating may be a preference for some users. Contrast rations below 2 and pairs of complementary colours (cyan, magenta, yellow) are to be avoided.
A spreadsheet giving colour results for any two combinations and RGB and their inverted equivalent is available on request from colven@ace-centre.org.uk
WCAG 2.0 defines luminosity contrast at http://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG20/#contrast-ratiodef :

text:list-item.text:p: L1 is the relative luminance of the lighter of the colors, and
L2 is the relative luminance of the darker of the colors.

office:text.text:p: Note 1: Contrast ratios can range from 1 to 21 (commonly written 1:1 to 21:1).

Note 2: Because authors do not have control over user settings as to how text is rendered (for example font smoothing or anti-aliasing), the contrast ratio for text can be evaluated with anti-aliasing turned off.

Note 3: For the purpose of Success Criteria 1.4.3 and 1.4.6, contrast is measured with respect to the specified background over which the text is rendered in normal usage. If no background color is specified, then white is assumed.

Note 4: Background color is the specified color of content over which the text is to be rendered in normal usage. It is a failure if no background color is specified when the text color is specified, because the user's default background color is unknown and cannot be evaluated for sufficient contrast. For the same reason, it is a failure if no text color is specified when a background color is specified.

Note 5: When there is a border around the letter, the border can add contrast and would be used in calculating the contrast between the letter and its background. A narrow border around the letter would be used as the letter. A wide border around the letter that fills in the inner details of the letters acts as a halo and would be considered background.

Note 6: WCAG conformance should be evaluated for color pairs specified in the content that an author would expect to appear adjacent in typical presentation. Authors need not consider unusual presentations, such as color changes made by the user agent, except where caused by authors' code.132
The formula and notes are quoted from WCAG 2.0.
Relative luminance: the relative brightness of any point in a colorspace, normalized to 0 for darkest black and 1 for lightest white

text:p.text:span: For the sRGB colorspace, the relative luminance of a color is defined as L = 0.2126 *

text:list-item.text:p: RsRGB = R8bit/255
GsRGB = G8bit/255
BsRGB = B8bit/255

text:p.text:span: The "^" character is the exponentiation operator. (Formula taken from

Almost all systems used today to view Web content assume sRGB encoding. Unless it is known that another color space will be used to process and display the content, authors should evaluate using sRGB colorspace. If using other color spaces, see

If dithering occurs after delivery, then the source color value is used. For colors that are dithered at the source, the average values of the colors that are dithered should be used (average R, average G, and average B).
Tools are available that automatically do the calculations when testing contrast and flash.

text:a.text:span: MathML version of the relative luminance definition

text:note-body.text:p: The formula and notes are quoted from WCAG 2.0.

draw:text-box.text:p: Screenshot of the Windows Magnifier in lens mode hovering over a piece of text Illustration 15: Windows XP magnifier following mouse cursor I beam

office:text.text:p: Magnifiers are a common assistive technology to aid users with impaired sight. Basic magnifiers are supplied with some operating systems, Microsoft Windows and Mac OS X are two examples of systems with built-in magnifiers. Magnifiers usually grab graphical information directly from the screen and re-display it enlarged in a zoom window.

draw:text-box.text:p: Dialog with zoom options such as the range for rapid zooming, keyboard shortcuts, smoothing and how the screen image should move. Illustration 16: Mac OS X zoom tools

office:text.text:p: There are two basic styles of zoom, those with fixed locations and those that float over the screen following the mouse cursor, caret or editing focus. The fixed version is the more common.
For fixed zoom windows users set the screen location and size as well as the default zoom factor. With floating “magnifying glass” zoom, the size and zoom factor are required.
Zoom windows do take up “real estate” on the screen and applications should not interact in such a way as to interfere with the zoom window.
In order for magnifiers to follow the current focus of work systems and applications need to publish the position of the mouse cursor, text caret and/or editing or tab focus.

The size and thickness of the caret and its flash rate and the colour of the mouse cursor should all be magnified without other changes but some users may use inverted colours in the zoom window to make the zoom more obvious.

Another aid to using the zoom function is to have a method of locating caret and pointer. For example Mouse Locator in Mac OS X. In Windows XP, there is a setting that allows you to locate the pointer by pressing the Control key (Ctrl). A visual aid to the cursor position is in the form of a vanishing circle at the mouse cursor position is displayed. [Note: This setting is only available in the mouse settings panel and does not appear in any visual accessibility area panel, an example where mirroring of parameters would be useful.]

Some consideration needs to be given to how the use of multiple screens is accommodated. Zoom AT will need to operate in these situations following the caret, editing or tab focus across these screens. Applications and systems will need to publish appropriate data so that zoom AT can magnify the display either on one fixed (home) screen or on the current focussed screen.

Multi-touch environments are becoming more common in mobile and desktop environments. When multi-point information is available it should be published so that future zoom AT can utilise the platform correctly, perhaps by providing multi-window zooms.
Table 7: Example parameters

table:table-cell.text:p: 2 colour → 32 Million (interpolate from actual colours if using fewer colours)
Zoom factor (may be handled by AT)
Zoom Window (may be handled by AT)
Fixed/float (if fixed position top/bottom/left/right/ X and Y
Zoom action (may be handled by AT)
Scroll/follow cursor, caret text or tab focus
Any (Default but applications can change - user setting)
Any (Default but applications can change - user setting)
Typeface, Colour, Point, Style for use as application default (Also available to apply to application text (cf text size in browsers)
Any colour (→ to any colour for gradient fill)
Any colour (→ to any colour for gradient fill)
Set Background and foreground colours and text style (bold,Underscore etc. e.g. Format
Must not be able to set as same as normal or with text invisible.
Must not be able to set as same as normal or with text invisible.
Any but not near the bar colour
Any but not near the slider colour
Icon size – replaced with vector graphic
Message/Warning box (Font size, colour, etc. background colour)
As for menu parameters(usually handled by the system)

office:text.text:p:
In order to support control of an application through voice recognition (see for example VEDICS for the GNOME desktop134
VEDICS: https://sourceforge.net/projects/vedics/ ) an application needs to fulfil requirements that are also needed for access with on-screen keyboards (see 3.1.7above). In Java parlance, this would require the implementation of AccessibleAction, AccessibleSelection and AccessibleValue (with the ability to set the values). An additional requirement is the need to know the language or locale each UI component is in, in order to adjust the voice recognition models to the language used in a UI component.

text:p.text:span: Note: Language or locale information is not always covered by accessibility APIs. This information may be available through other means. For example, IAccessible 2 contains the struct “IA2Locale”, while Java uses
the class java.util.Locale to represent to represent locale-sensitive information (language, country and variant)

text:note-body.text:p: “Class Locale” in JavaTM 2 Platform, Standard Edition, v 1.4.2 API Specification: http://download.oracle.com/javase/1.4.2/docs/api/java/util/Locale.html

office:text.text:p: Sending fake keypress events from an alternative input mechanism like Dasher requires a solution to the problem of managing focus. An AT library would make sending keypresses easier. (The change from CORBA to DBUS in GNOME does not solve this problem for GOK, either.) This process sits at a lower level than what the developer should be working on. A loadable software keyboard interface API like Android is easier to work with for developers.

Support for the CCF-API, making it possible to input concept code references (with default text representations) directly into the document content of CCF compliant content editors (OpenOffice.org being the first obvious example).
A component/widget should be defined, developed and provided in suitable flavours for a range of most important development environments, for easy inclusion into new applications and services.

Speech synthesis has long been a vital assistive technology tool and its application in this area is significant and widespread. It allows environmental barriers to be removed for people with a wide range of disabilities. The longest application has been in the use of screen readers for people with visual impairments, but text-to-speech systems are now commonly used by people with dyslexia and other reading difficulties as well as by pre-literate youngsters. They are also frequently employed to aid those with severe speech impairment usually through a dedicated voice output communication aid.
The following sections analyse the requirements of systems that need to use the capabilities of a TTS engine.

Text to speech, TTS, is the automatic conversion of unrestricted text into speech. The device or computer program that does this is a TTS synthesizer; if it is a computer program it is often called a TTS Engine.
A typical TTS engine comprises several components. Depending on the nature of a particular TTS engine, these include components which:

text:list-item.text:p: resolve ambiguities in the text, such as converting Mr to Mister, recognising dates and currencies as differing from ordinary numbers;

convert the text to symbols or phonemes representing the corresponding speech sounds using a lexicon, a set of simple rules, a statistical method predicting likely pronunciations, or a combination of these;
generate prosodic information, which describes how to speak the sounds in terms of their duration and the pitch of the voice;
convert the phonemes and prosody to an audio speech signal.

office:text.text:p: Other sub-systems may also be used, but all TTS engines have components that correspond to the above list. Some of these can be very sophisticated and may for instance use natural language processing to resolve text ambiguities. The last stage, the one that turns a phonetic and prosodic description of the desired speech into a speech signal is often used to label the type of TTS Engine, perhaps because this stage broadly determines what the synthesized speech sounds like.

The most important qualities of a speech synthesis system are naturalness and intelligibility. Naturalness describes how closely the output sounds like human speech, while intelligibility is the ease with which the output is understood. The ideal speech synthesizer is both natural and intelligible. Speech synthesis systems usually try to maximize both characteristics.

The two primary technologies for generating synthetic speech waveforms are concatenative synthesis and formant synthesis. There are also other types of engines, such as synthesis based on Hidden Markov Models (HMM), which recently started gaining momentum, articulatory synthesis and sinewave synthesis.

There are several ways a speech engine can be used from the accessibility systems such as the screen readers. Some ways, such as using the engine as a shared library, is tightly coupled with the system and offers less flexibility, while others, such as using it through a back-end library, is more flexible.
office:text.text:h: As a shared library or dynamic-link library
office:text.text:p: One of the most common ways of using an engine, is by linking to it through the engine’s shared libraries or dynamic-links libraries (DLLs). In this approach, the systems that use the TTS engine are tightly coupled with the engine. This means that, at compile time, the program needs to know which engine it uses, and use its specific API.

However this is not a preferred approach for an accessibility framework like OAF, because the accessibility framework needs to be as application-agnostic as possible when providing services like these, so that when new TTS engines are available they should be available for use by the framework without any changes in the Framework and/or application source code.
office:text.text:h: Through a back-end library – Higher Lever Interface
office:text.text:p: One solution to the problem above is for the framework to provide a higher lever interface for speech synthesis (either an existing one or a new one). When using higher level interfaces, the cost the development support passes from the OAF framework to the TTS engine. It should be the responsibility of the TTS engine developers to provide support for this higher level API by developing “drivers” of their engine to this higher lever interface. There are three such existing interfaces that are well known, widely used and open source: GNOME Speech, Speech Dispatcher and AT-SPI.

The GNOME speech component of GNOME136
The GNOME Project: “GNOME Speech” http://live.gnome.org/Orca/GnomeSpeech provides a service-based approach to speech synthesis engines. Each speech engine that is installed on the system can be exposed as a speech service by GNOME speech, allowing assistive technologies such as the Orca Screen Reader to share the resource. Most of the available synthesis engines on the Open Solaris and Linux platforms are available via GNOME speech.

GNOME speech has a number of limitations, one of which is that it is bound to the GNOME desktop. People want speech to be more of a session and/or system service that can be used across desktop solutions (e.g., GNOME, KDE and others) as well as at the console level for applications such BrlTTY. [The text suggests that there are other limitations but they are not mentioned. Are they relevant to accessibility?]

One more problem for GNOME Speech is that it is based upon Bonobo/CORBA. Bonobo is deprecated and will be removed from future Gnome versions137
The GNOME Project: “Bonobo and CORBA” http://library.gnome.org/devel/platform-overview/stable/bonobo-corba.html.en The GNOME Project: “Accessibiliyt/BonoboDeprecation”:http://live.gnome.org/Accessibility/BonoboDeprecation , which means that maybe development will be stalled on GNOME speech.

The goal of Speech Dispatcher project138
Speech Dispatcher: http://www.freebsoft.org/speechd. Hynek Hanke: “Speech Dispatcher: Common interface to speech synthesis” aKademy 2005: http://accessibility.kde.org/events/akademy2005/speech-dispatcher/speechd.pdf is to provide a high-level device-independent layer for speech synthesis through a simple, stable and well documented interface.
Key features:

text:list-item.text:p: common interface to different TTS engines;
handling concurrent synthesis requests – requests may come asynchronously from multiple sources within an application and/or from more different applications;
subsequent serialization, resolution of conflicts and priorities of incoming requests;
context switching – state is maintained for each client connection independently, event for connections from within one application;
high-level client interfaces for popular programming languages;
common sound output handling – audio playback is handled by Speech Dispatcher rather than the TTS engine, since most engines have limited sound output capabilities.

office:text.text:p: What a very high level GUI library is to graphics, Speech Dispatcher is to speech synthesis. The application neither needs to talk to the devices directly nor to handle concurrent access, sound output and other tricky aspects of the speech subsystem.
Speech Dispatcher supports the following TTS engines:

text:list-item.text:p: Festival
Flite
Espeak
Cicero
IBM TTS
Espeak+MBROLA (through a generic driver)
Epos (through a generic driver)
DecTalk software (through a generic driver)
Cepstral Swift (through a generic driver)

office:text.text:p:
The architecture is based on a client/server model. The clients are all the applications in the system that want to produce speech (typically assistive technologies). The basic means of client communication with Speech Dispatcher is through a TCP connection using the Speech Synthesis Interface Protocol (SSIP)139
See the SSIP documentation for more information: http://cvs.freebsoft.org/doc/speechd/ssip.html. . High-level client libraries for many popular programming languages implement this protocol to make its usage as simple as possible.
Speech Dispatcher is the choice for the upcoming Gnome 3.0 since GNOME Speech and its CORBA interface is deprecated.

Regarding the accessibility applications that need a TTS engine, it should be preferable to use higher lever APIs such as Speech Dispatcher, that will be supported by Accessibility Frameworks such as OAF. This way, the accessibility? applications become application agnostic and focus on standard APIs for their functionality, with future TTS engine support.

On the other hand, TTS engine developers should provide drivers for such higher level APIs that are supported by Accessibility Frameworks such as OAF. This way they will have a broader user base and will provide support to Accessibility Standards.
All components in a user interface (UI) component library should implement the accessibility API.
The WAI ARIA draft recommendation lists the following as the “first steps to making an application accessible”:

text:list-item.text:p: Each element or widget has correct and complete semantics that fully describe its behavior (using element names or roles);
The relationships between elements and groups are defined;
States, properties, and container relationships are valid for each element's behavior and are accessible via the Document Object Model [DOM] and the platform accessibility API; and
Keyboard focus should be maintained for the duration of the user's interaction with the application.
All interactive components should be keyboard operable.
Section 2 of the “WAI-ARIA Best Practices” (Pappas et al, 2009) expands on each of these steps.

office:text.text:p: More specifically: a UI element component may need to be provided to allow full Ruby Annotation based, vertically aligned, display of text with graphic symbol representations to be easily included into desktop, web and mobile applications.

Better support for keyboard-controlled content focus navigation (in addition to link navigation) in standard web content/documents – for TTS reading – with visual highlighting and graphic symbol cueing. Support for focus granularity – paragraph, sentence, word, character.(This is to avoid the need for complicated dynamic DOM tree hacking to handle these tasks)
Like the Authoring Tool Accessibility Guidelines (ATAG), we can distinguish two types of requirements:

text:list-item.text:p: requirements regarding the production of accessible content;
requirements for the accessibility of the developer tool itself.

office:text.text:p: A developer tool should enable the developer implement the steps quoted from WAI-ARIA in the previous section (“Requirements for User Interface Components”). For example, when a developer drags an edit field from a palette onto a frame, it should be easy to add all the accessibility metadata (name, role, relation, ...).

In addition, the developer tool should recommend adaptations according to the userprofile, if applicable. The tool should also check the accessibility of the designed application with respect to the user profile.

text:p.text:span: ISO/IEC Guide 71: 2001: “Guidelines for standards developers to address the needs of older persons and persons with disabilities” and its European equivalent

are strictly speaking aimed at working groups or committees in standardisation rather than developers. It contains general guidelines, i.e. guidelines that cover all kinds of products and services, not just ICT.
CEN/CENELEC Guide 6 has three goals (quoted from

text:list-item.text:p: to inform how human abilities (and disabilities) affect the usability of products, services and the built environment,
2. to describe how requirements in standards relate to accessibility and usability of products and services,
to raise awareness about the benefits of accessible design.

office:text.text:p: For readers not involved in standardisation, the most interesting parts are clauses 7, 8 and 9. Clause 7 contains tables of factors to consider to ensure that standards provide for accessible design. In the context of ICT, the most relevant of these tables is table 5: “Factors to consider in clauses on the user interface” (see Annex 1).

Clause 8 discusses factors to consider in accessible design, such as alternative formats (8.1), colour and contrast (8.5), clear language in written and spoken information (8.7), etcetera. Many of these factors are not relevant to ICT, for example, expiration date marking (8.13), surface temperature (8.14), ventilation (8.22).

Clause 9 discusses details about human abilities and the consequences of impairment. This can be useful for readers who are new to accessibility, but more detailed descriptions exist elsewhere (see for example, ISO/TR 22411).

text:p.text:span: ISO/TR 22411:2008: “Ergonomics data and guidelines for the application of ISO/IEC Guide 71 to products and services to address the needs of older persons and persons with disabilities” is a companion to ISO/IEC Guide 71 and its European equivalent CEN/CENELEC Guide 6. It uses the same structure as the ISO and CEN guides and provides more detailed information for each clause in those guides. For example, it provides more details on alternatives to auditory information (8.2.3), on colour and contrast (8?5: choice of colour, colour combinations, colour coding if information)
, clear language in written and spoken information (8.7), etcetera.
Clause 9 provides basic knowledge and ergonomic data on human abilities and the consequences of impairmen

t. It puts special emphasis on describing how human abilities change between youth and old age. Clause 9 also provides statistics for some human abilities. For example, clause 9.2.1.2.1 describes the effect of viewing distance on visual acuity for seven age groups,
9.2.2.1 describes how hearing sensitivity decreases with age,
clause 9.3.1.2 provides data on hand steadiness, eye-hand coordination and grip diameter for different age groups and
describes the processing speed of inte
llectual activities as a function of age.
ISO 9241-171:2008: “Ergonomics of human-system interaction — Part 171: Guidance on software accessibility”
16071:2003 (“Ergonomics of human-system interaction — Guidance on accessibility for human-computer interfaces”), and cancels and replaces that standard.
ISO 9241-171 provides guidance on the design of interactive systems to make those systems as accessible as possible.
Because design that increases accessibility also promotes
increased effectiveness, efficiency and satisfaction for people with a wide variety of capabilities and preferences, accessibility is highly related to usability, which is covered in ISO 9241-11).
ISO 9241-171 does not assume any specific software design method or process but is

complementary to existing design methods. The standard defines a number of requirements (“shall” statements) and recommendations (“should” statements); conformance to the standard can be achieved by satisfying all the applicable requirements and by the provision of a list of all the recommendations that have been satisfied. The standard does not cover the behaviour of or the requirements for assistive technologies.
Below is the table of ISO 9241-171 subclauses that contain requirements
which must be met in order to claim conformance to the standard.

office:text.text:p: Table 8: ISO 9241-171 requirements

table:table-cell.text:p: Provide a name for each user-interface element
Make names available to assistive technology
This requires a comprehensive accessibility API; see OAF step 1
Enable individualization of the cursor and pointer
See 3.2 Theming Support, Text Resizing, Magnification and Zooming
Enable user control of timed responses
Make controls for accessibility features discoverable and operable
Provide alternatives when assistive technology is not available
Allow warning or error information to persist
Enable communication between software and assistive technology
This requires a comprehensive accessibility API; see OAF step 1
Make user-interface element information available to assistive technologies
Allow assistive technology to change keyboard focus and selection
Make event notification available to assistive technologies

This is very vague: accessibility features for tables vary across technologies (e.g. HTML, MS Word formats, MS Excel formats, Open Document Text); support by screen readers also varies (for example, a screenreader may support for merged table header cells in MS Excel but not in MS Word).
Accept the installation of keyboard and/or pointing device emulators
Allow assistive technology to monitor output operations
Provide parallel keyboard control of pointer functions
Provide keyboard focus and text cursors
Provide high visibility keyboard focus and text cursors
Keyboard navigation scheme is part of OAF step 1
Enable sequential entry of multiple (chorded) keystrokes
Provide adjustment of delay before key acceptance
Provide adjustment of same-key double-strike acceptance
Allow users to turn key repeat off
Provide direct control of pointer position from external devices
Enable the reassignment of pointing-device button functions
Provide a means of finding the pointer
Provide alternatives to simultaneous pointer operations
Enable user control of time-sensitive presentation of information
Provide accessible alternatives to task-relevant audio and video
Provide keyboard access to information displayed outside the physical screen
Do not convey information by colour output alone
Enable non-pointer navigation directly to windows
Provide user control of multiple “always-on-top” windows
Enable windows to avoid taking focus
Allow users to choose visual alternative for audio output
Synchronize audio equivalents for visual events
Enable users to stop, start and pause
Provide user documentation in accessible electronic form
Provide text alternatives in electronic documentation and “Help”
Provide documentation and “Help” on accessibility features

office:text.text:p: This document has described the problems of current and older access techniques and introduced the concept of third-generation accessibility. The bulk of the document described the current state of accessibility on a number of platforms (including Microsoft Windows, GNOME, Mac OS and Java): accessibility APIs, keyboard operation, theming support, alternative input mechanisms, and synthetic speech. It provides a basis for the Open Accessibility Framework, which is defined in deliverable D1.2.1.
